DOC.HEAD: Five Dead in Unrelated Plane Crashes
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine airplane crashed in thick fog in northern California, killing three people, and authorities Sunday found two dead in the wreckage of a small plane in north Georgia that had been missing for 10 days. In St. Louis, a Missouri Air National Guard F-4 pilot and crew member were injured when the fighter jet veered off a runway and burst into flames during a training exercise takeoff. The F-4's weapons system operator suffered multiple fractures, including his ankle and pelvis, when he ejected from the rear seat 50 feet into the air during the crash at Lambert Airport, said Air National Guard Capt. Darrell Shoults. The pilot suffered only bruises. In Arcata, Calif., the wreckage of a single-engine plane was found Saturday in a mountainous area about one mile from a landing strip at Kneeland Mountain, the Humboldt County Sheriff's Department said. Walt Davis of Elk Grove and Merle Stone of Tulare and his wife, name unknown, died in the crash, said sheriff's dispatcher Skip Arnold. Davis' wife, Carol, survived the crash. She was taken to General Hospital in Eureka, then to the University of California Medical Center in Sacramento for burn treatment. The wreckage of a Piper PA-28 Cherokee 160 that disappeared March 29, was found Sunday just east of Ellijay, Ga. The bodies of Daryl Raisly, 31, of Henryville, Ind., and passenger Jesse Leland Street, 32, of Louisville, Ky., were recovered, said 2nd Lt. Warren Bates of the Georgia Civil Air Patrol. The four-seat aircraft, which left Lakeland, Fla., on March 29 for Sellersburg, Ind., was last seen when it made a fuel stop at Perry, Ga.

DOC.HEAD: Motley Crue Drummer Injured During Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Urtz said ...,' to DELETE now-outdated sentence on Lee's release from hospital.
DOC.TEXT: Tommy Lee, a drummer with the flamboyant heavy metal rock group Motley Crue, suffered a mild concussion when he fell during a concert at the New Haven Coliseum, authorities said Sunday. Lee, 26, fell to the floor Saturday while swinging down a rope from on-stage scaffolding, and was in good condition at Yale-New Haven Hospital, said hospital spokesman Tom Urtz. ``He is alert, awake and in good spirits,'' Urtz said. Lee was released late Sunday afternoon, a hospital spokeswoman said. Urtz said Sunday morning that he did not know how Lee fell except that the rappelling stunt ``was part of the routine. The heavily tattooed drummer is married to actress Heather Locklear. Motley Crue is scheduled to perform Tuesday in Binghamton, N.Y. Before launching its tour, the band pledged that even though all members had undergone drug rehabilitation, its concerts would be just as raucous as in the past. ``We don't just play rock 'n' roll, we live it,'' bassist Nikki Sixx was quoted as saying in People magazine earlier this year. ``We go on tour and get broken bones, diseases, the crowd leaves bloody. It's more like going to war.'' Two teen-agers filed a $1.3 million suit against the band for injuries allegedly suffered when pieces of dry ice flew from the stage during a 1985 concert in Alabama. The case ended in a mistrial.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Thoroughbred Breeder Leslie Combs Dead at 88
DOC.TEXT: Leslie Combs II, founder of Spendthrift Farm, once one of the premier thoroughbred horse breeding operations, died Saturday at the University of Kentucky Medical Center. He was 88. The hospital did not disclose the cause of death. Spendthrift, started in 1936, grew from 126 acres to nearly 6,000 and once was the home of Triple Crown winners Seattle Slew and Affirmed. Combs was a pioneer of modern racehorse syndication, getting 20 investors to put up $5,000 each in the stallion Beau Pere in the 1940s. He later syndicated such outstanding horses as Nashua, Majestic Prince and Raise a Native. Combs was the first horseman to sell at yearling for $100,000 and the first to syndicate a stallion for $1 million. His boldest move was taking Spendthrift public in 1984. The farm filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy four years later, and bankers agreed to forgive the farm's $7.8 million debt. Horsemen Henry Hershey, Curtis Green and William duPont III bought the farm's assets last year. Thomas Meeker, president of Churchill Downs Inc. in Louisville, called Combs' death ``a great loss to the thoroughbred industry.'' ``He'll be remembered as the master of Spendthrift Farm, one of the greatest breeding operations in the world,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: China Suspends Relations With Lesotho
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to CORRECT that relations suspended not broken; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: China suspended diplomatic relations with Lesotho on Saturday, two days after the small African nation established ties with Taiwan. The official Xinhua News Agency had reported in English that Beijing decided to ``break off'' relations with Lesotho, but this appeared to be a mistranslation. Chinese-language reports said Beijing suspended ties, as it has with three other small countries that recently recognized Taiwan _ Grenada, Liberia and Belize. China accused Lesotho of violating its pledge to recognize the People's Republic of China as the sole legal government of China. Taiwan, an island province of China, is governed by the Nationalists who fled the mainland in 1949 after being defeated by the Communists in a civil war. The Nationalists still claim to be the rightful rulers of all China. Lesotho, a kingdom with a population of 1.6 million surrounded by South Africa, established relations with Beijing in 1983.

DOC.TEXT: Ronald E. Evans, Apollo 17 command module pilot on man's last trip to the moon, died of a heart attack at his Arizona home Saturday. He was 56. The former astronaut died in his sleep and was found by his wife, Janet, his mother-in-law, Marge Pollom of Sun City, told the The Topeka Capital-Journal. Evans called his December 1972 flight to the moon in Apollo 17 ``the best experience I ever had in my life.'' He left the astronaut program in 1977 to become an officer with Western American Energy Corp. in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was in demand as a public speaker and traveled widely. Evans was born in St. Francis, Kan., and later lived in Topeka, Kan. He received a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from the University of Kansas in 1956, where he enrolled in the ROTC program, and a master's degree in aeronautical engineering from the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School in 1964. He was selected in 1963 for astronaut training and became an astronaut in 1966.

The Rev. W. Harold Flowers, a patriarch of the civil rights movement in Arkansas and the oldest practicing black attorney in the state, died Saturday at a Little Rock hospital. He was 78 and had been suffering from cancer. ``His leadership, his compassion and spiritual example touched so many lives,'' Gov. Bill Clinton said. ``He deserves the recognition in breaking the ice to enable blacks to participate on equal basis with other attorneys in representing their clients,'' U.S. District Judge George Howard Jr. said. In one of his most celebrated trials, Flowers in 1947 defended two black men who had been charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of two white men. His motion to quash the entire jury on the grounds that there had been no black jurors in nearly 50 years led to the placement of 13 blacks on the prospective jurors' panel, with three eventually seated on the jury. The defendants were found guilty of lesser charges, marking the first time in Arkansas that a black man had not gone to the electric chair upon conviction in the death of a white man. Flowers was ordained as a Methodist minister in 1971. In 1977, he was the first black named a special circuit judge for Jefferson County. In 1980, Clinton appointed Flowers as an associate justice of the state Court of Appeals. A founder and former president of the National Bar Association, he was inducted into the association's Hall of Fame in 1986 and was a past president of the American Bar Association and past state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

Retired thorougbred owner and breeder Leslie Combs II, founder of Spendthrift Farm and known as a pioneer of racehorse syndication, died Saturday at the University of Kentucky Medical Center. He was 88. Thomas Meeker, president of Churchill Downs Inc. in Louisville, called Combs' death ``a great loss to the thoroughbred industry.'' ``He'll be remembered as the master of Spendthrift Farm, one of the greatest breeding operations in the world,'' he said. Spendthrift, started in 1936, once was renowned as a premier thoroughbred breeding operation, growing from 126 acres to nearly 6,000. It once was the home of Triple Crown winners Seattle Slew and Affirmed. Combs became known as the ``pioneer of modern racehorse syndication,'' when he set a deal of 20 investors for $5,000 each in the stallion Beau Pere in the 1940s. He later syndicated such outstanding horses as Nashua, Majestic Prince and Raise a Native. Combs was the first horseman to sell at yearling for $100,000 and the first to syndicate a stallion for $1 million.
DOC.HEAD: Arthur Singer
DOC.TEXT: Arthur B. Singer, a naturalist and painter whose watercolors of state birds were affixed to hundreds of thousands of letters mailed in the 1980s, died of cancer Saturday. He was 72. The stamp series bearing Singer's paintings is believed to have been the largest-selling special issue in the history of U.S. postage. The Postal Service issued the stamps featuring the birds and flowers of the 50 states in 1982. Singer, who graduated from the Cooper Union Art School in New York in 1939, received its Augustus St. Gaudens Medal in 1962 after 750 of his paintings appeared in ``Birds of the World,'' the first of many books he illustrated. Golden Press issued a new edition of the book in 1983. He received the Hal Borland Award from the National Audubon Society in 1985, on the 200th anniversary of Audubon's birth.
DOC.HEAD: Adolf Pabst
DOC.TEXT: Adolf Pabst, a mineralogy expert at the University of California at Berkeley whose research was honored when a California silicate was named after him, died Tuesday at age 90. Pabst taught in Berkeley for 40 years and lectured around the world on his work in crystal deformation. He received the Roebling Medal, the highest honor bestowed by the Mineralogical Society of America, which he served as president in 1951. Fellow scientists at Berkeley named a California mineral Pabstite in honor of his work in 1965.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Aid Benefit Concert Returns With Environmental Focus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 2 grafs with event finale; pick up 2nd graf, `Farm Aid ...'. SUBS 15th graf pvs, `Carolyn Mugar ...', to UPDATE revenue estimate; pick up 16th graf pvs, `Mugar said ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NA2, 12
DOC.TEXT: Financially strapped Farm Aid returned Saturday with its first concert in 2{ years. Performers sounded a message of concern not only for the family farmer but also for the land they till. The concert crammed with more than 60 acts lasted nearly 14 hours, finishing after midnight. It concluded with an all-star chorus singing ``This Land is Your Land,'' led by Arlo Guthrie, son of the song's composer, Woody Guthrie. Farm Aid President Willie Nelson topped the list of performers who said they were forging a coalition with family farmers, environmentalists and consumers to work toward reducing the amount of chemicals used in food production. ``Somewhere between a lot of chemicals and no chemicals there's a happy medium,'' Nelson said at a news conference before performing the first song of the 12-hour show in the Hoosier Dome. ``As experts, the farmers will have to tell you how much do they need (and) how much are they forced to use,'' Nelson said. ``I think that's the difference. If they can get enough money for a bushel of corn, they don't have to drain that acre for every ounce that's in it.'' Inside the arena, early arrivals among the sellout crowd of 45,000 settled in with blankets and pillows for the marathon event. Many of the more popular performers, including Neil Young, Bonnie Raitt and Don Henley, didn't perform until the final two hours. Elton John made an unexpected appearance late in the program and performed three songs. The British rock singer-pianist had been in Indianapolis to visit critically ill teen-age AIDS victim Ryan White, a close friend. ``This one's for Ryan,'' John said before beginning ``Candle in the Wind,'' a song he wrote about the tragic life of Marilyn Monroe. Afterward, the crowd delivered its biggest ovation of the show. John's set provided a somber note during a day of activism on behalf of family farmers and the environment. The Rev. Jesse Jackson said the family farm crisis is expanding. ``Since 1980, we've lost about 75,000 farms largely because farmers couldn't earn enough from their crops to pay their bills,'' he said. Jackson criticized reports from Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter citing farm income at record levels, a point some Farm Aid critics have raised as evidence this concert was unnecessary. ``What (Yeutter) doesn't say is that when the numbers are adjusted for inflation, farm income in the last decade was at its lowest since 1910,'' he said. Singer Henry Lee Summer, from Brazil, Ind., used the stage to speak out against out-of-state trash being dumped in Indiana. ``I've got a message to all those big businesses that want to dump all their trash and toxic waste here: We don't deserve it,'' Summer said, drawing a big cheer. Concertgoers said they were there not only to enjoy the music but also to support the family farmer, the cause that inspired the formation of Farm Aid five years ago. The organization, through its first three shows in 1985-87, raised $12 million and has distributed some $9 million to churches and service agencies, hotlines and farm organizations. Carolyn Mugar, executive director of Farm Aid, said late in the evening that the show had generated well over $1 million in revenues and donations. She and Nelson have left open the possibility of more concerts as the need for money arises. Mugar said Farm Aid IV was arranged because the organization has run out of money. It was staged two weeks before the nation observes the 20th anniversary of Earth Day in part as a way of stressing that the farm and environmental causes are intertwined. ``When we restore the honor and sanctity of the family farmer, in conjunction with Earth Day _ which is not just lip service and not just one event _ we restore the sanctity and honor of Mother Earth herself,'' Raitt said. Environmental activists, including Chris Desser, executive director of Earth Day 1990, and John O'Connor, executive director of the National Toxics Campaign, also spoke out against ``brute chemical farming.'' O'Connor said a third of the nation's farm crop is still lost to insects and other pests, just as it was before World War II, despite a tenfold increase in chemical use. The lineup at the Hoosier Dome also included Dwight Yoakum, K.T. Oslin, Lou Reed, Guns N' Roses, Richard Marx, Jackson Browne, John Denver and a Soviet rock band, Gorky Park. Huge black and white cutouts of farm workers with cows and farm implements were the stage backdrop. Hanging on the left and right sides of the stage were huge flags with the Farm Aid logo of a tractor with an American flag. Farm Aid's first concert in September 1985 was in Champaign, Ill. Subsequent concerts were held in 1986 in Austin, Texas, and in 1987 in Lincoln, Neb.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarians Vote in Runoffs For Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Hungarians voted Sunday in a runoff election for the nation's first freely elected multiparty legislature since 1947, and former Communists were widely expected to serve only in the opposition. No party was thought likely to win an outright majority in the polling, which began at 6 a.m. in most areas. Preliminary results were not expected before midnight, six hours after the polls closed. The first round of balloting almost two weeks ago left 261 of the 394 seats undecided in the National Assembly. But it gave two anti-Communist parties a firm lead and relegated reform Communists, now running as the Socialist Party, to fourth place with 10 percent of the vote. The two frontrunners, the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum and the liberal-leftist League of Free Democrats, have said they will not accept the Socialists as coalition partners. Many still associate the Socialist party with the hard-line Communists who ruled Hungary for 43 years. The two leading parties have been reluctant to comment publicly on the prospects of a coalition, but the Free Democrats have said they would not rule out a joint government with the Democratic Forum. A broad coalition is considered by many as the only government stable enough to make the hard decisions necessary to correct a stagnant economy while reining in a $20 billion national debt. But a coalition with a consensus on economic policy could be difficult to forge, since the leading parties have different views on the pacing and scope of economic reforms. Twenty-nine parties fielded candidates in the first round, but only six reached the 4 percent minimum required for a seat in Parliament. Candidates in the March 25 elections disputed 176 seats in direct balloting in electoral districts. A clear winner emerged in only five of those districts. They included Socialist Premier Miklos Nemeth, a reformer who enjoys considerable popularity in the country. An additional 210 seats were contested on the basis of the proportion of the vote parties received in the voting. Another eight seats are reserved for national minorities. After the first round, 120 seats were assigned on the basis of proportional voting. The remaining 90 seats will be assigned on a proportional basis following Sunday's voting.

DOC.HEAD: Greeks Vote For Third Time Within a year
DOC.TEXT: Greeks cast ballots in their third parliamentary election in ten months Sunday, amid projections that no party would win the outright majority needed to govern. In Athens, long queues formed outside many polling stations when they opened at 7:01 a.m.. Polls were scheduled to close at sunset, or 7:54 p.m.. More than 8 million voters chose among candidates from 27 parties, two coalitions and 16 independent groupings that stretched across the political spectrum. Voting is mandatory for Greeks between 18 and 70 years of age. Only three parties were considered likely to attract significant numbers of voters: the conservative New Democracy, the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) and the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress. But Sunday's election, like those last June and November, could end without a clear winner and again leave Greece with a weak coalition unable to cope with a foundering economy and a resurgence of terrorism. The outcome may also have bearing on the country's four U.S. military bases, which could close in November unless a new agreement is reached with Washington. Election officials said first results would be in hand two hours after the polls closed and definitive results, by early Tuesday. In the two previous elections, New Democracy defeated PASOK, led by former premier Andreas Papandreou, but fell short of winning an absolute majority in the 300-member single house Parliament. Opinion polls indicated New Democracy, led by 71-year-old Constantine Mitsotakis, was also the frontrunner in Sunday's voting but could again fail to achieve the necessary majority to govern alone. Such a result could lead to difficult negotiations between the three top parties over a ruling coalition _ and possibly another round of elections. Papandreou, 71, has said he will attempt a ``progressive'' alliance with the Communist-led Coalition to govern for the next four years. Last June, New Democracy teamed with the Coalition, its ideological opponents, to govern from July to October. The government was formed under the limited mandate of investigating corruption charges against Papandreou and five of his ministers. The Parliament indicted Papandreou on charges of ordering telephone tapping of political opponents and involvement in a $210 million Bank of Crete embezzlement scandal. The corruption charges helped bring down Papandreou's government but the charismatic leader continues to be a political force. Papandreou has denied the charges. No date has been set for his trial. In the November elections, New Democracy won 46.19 percent of the vote for 148 seats, PASOK, 40.67 percent for 128 places and the Coalition, 10.97 percent for 21 seats.

DOC.HEAD: Slovenia Holds First Free Elections Since 1945
DOC.TEXT: Slovenians voted Sunday in the first free elections in Yugoslavia since World War II, ending 45 years of Communist monopoly on power in the republic. The 1.5 million registered voters will choose Slovenia's new president, four members of the ruling collective presidency and 240 members of the new multiparty Parliament. The 4,130 polls in the republic opened at 7 a.m. and were to close 12 hours later. Preliminary results are expected early Monday and official results are due Tuesday. Electoral laws require a runoff on April 22 between the top two vote-getters if no presidential candidate receives more than 50 percent. Four candidates are running for the republic's presidency. The principal election issues were whether or not Slovenia should remain within the troubled federation and solutions for the inflation-racked economy. Milan Kucan, a candidate of the reformist Slovenian Communist party, which recently renamed itself the Party for Democratic Renewal, was ahead in the oppinion polls for the presidency. His toughest opponent for the top post was former dissident Joze Pucnik, a candidate of DEMOS, a coalition of five center-right parties. Pre-elections polls gave little chance to the other two presidential candidates Pucnik, a professor of philosophy, spent seven years in Slovenian prisons during the 1950s for his opposition to communism. He was forced to emigrate to West Germany from where he returned only last year after spending more than 20 years in exile. Slovenians are increasingly showing a desire to secede from Yugoslavia because they are unhappy with the slow pace of democratic and other reforms in the rest of the country. Slovenia's reform-minded Communists have moved quickly over the past three years to create a pluralistic system in the republic. The reforms in Slovenia have been implemented despite harsh criticism from Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, where Communist leaders demand continued Communist party dominance. Croatia, the second largest republic, is also scheduled to stage free parliamentary elections later in April. Despite allowing the formation of oposition parties, Communists in other four republics, including Serbia, have not yet announced free elections. Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces. It is ruled by an eight-man collective presidency.

DOC.HEAD: China's Urban Workforce Declines
DOC.TEXT: China's urban workforce declined by 1.5 million in the first two months of 1990, with smaller collective firms showing the largest loss of workers, an official daily said Sunday. The drop in working people continued a yearlong slump in the labor market caused by government austerity measures that have curbed inflation but brought economic growth to a standstill. Millions of factories around the country have closed down or are operating at a reduced pace because of a lack of raw materials and operating funds. The China Daily, quoting State Statistical Bureau figures, said the workforce stood at 136 million at the end of February, down 1.5 million from the end of 1989. State-owned enterprises employed 100.4 million people, a drop of 713,000, while collectively owned businesses had 34.3 million workers, 726,000 fewer than in December. Private businesses had 1.3 million workers on their payrolls, a decline of 58,000. The figures do not include the 100 million unneeded laborers in the countryside, where 800 million of China's 1.1 billion people live.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill 15 in Raid on Rebel Base in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Troops killed 15 in a raid on a Communist guerrilla base in the central Philippines, the military said Sunday. The military said the dead included a 13-year-old girl, whom they identified as the daughter of a rebel in the Marxist New People's Army. The military said troops raided the base, in Negros Occidental, 310 miles southeast of Manila, on Friday. Also Sunday, the military said troops captured a suspected Communist intelligence officer during a raid in Bataan peninsula. Military spokesman Col. Rene Esdado said Robert Omega was arrested in a house in Mariveles, 64 miles southwest of the capital. Omega is believed to be a rebel intelligence officer operating in Manila and the neighboring Rizal province, Esdado said. Soldiers seized a pistol, several bullets and a hand grenade.

DOC.HEAD: Four Networks Plan Shuttle Coverage
With AM-Hubble Trouble, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN plan to televise the scheduled launch of the shuttle Discovery live Tuesday morning. The spacecraft is scheduled to lift off at 8:47 a.m. EDT from the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral, Fla. During the five-day trip into space, five astronauts will put into orbit the Hubble Space Telescope, which will give scientists a look at stars and galaxies light years away. CNN plans to begin coverage from the space center at 5:30 a.m. EDT Tuesday, according to a statement issued by CNN. ABC's coverage will begin during ``Good Morning America,'' and then go to a special report, according to Arnot Walker, an ABC spokesman. CBS will carry the liftoff live as part of its ``CBS This Morning'' news show, said Tina Wynn, a spokeswoman for CBS. NBC will air the launch on the ``Today'' morning news show, said NBC spokeswoman Katherine McQuay.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians See Better Future in Being Small and Free
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The material for this report was gathered before the Soviet government expelled Ann Imse and other Western correspondents from Lithuania on April 1.

Many Lithuanians say their declaration of independence was like leaping for a lifeboat to escape a sinking ship. ``Alone, we know it will be better in five years; with them, we don't,'' banker Gintautas Preidis said of the Lithuanian parliament's decision March 11 to cut loose from the Soviet Union and its economic and ethnic problems. Lithuanians expect initial difficulties in switching from central planning and subsidies to a market economy in which prices are set by competition. The republic may also lose access to cheap Soviet resources. ``I visited a collective farm where they had 30 people as bookkeepers!'' said Joseph Kazickas, a Lithuanian who emigrated to the United States at the end of World War II and became a businessman. He is back in Lithuania, arranging for experts to help reform the economy and working with Premier Kazimieras Prunskiene to set up a system that would entice Western investment. The Kremlin, which has used troops to take over Lithuania's prosecutor's office and has waged a war of nerves to keep the republic in its fold, is standing in the way of some reform and could stifle other moves to revamp the republic's economy. Mrs. Prunskiene has said Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and his Cabinet refused to transfer most authority from Moscow to Vilnius. For example, Prunskiene suggested that the majority of the 200-plus factories now run by ministries in Moscow be turned over to Lithuanian control. Ryzhkov and his ministers are willing to hand over only a few dozen. Lithuanian officials aim for their nation of 3.8 million people, about the size and population of Ireland, to develop a thriving economy based on selling meat, milk and consumer goods to the Soviet Union and shipping its imports and exports. But Moscow built many of Lithuania's factories according to no economic logic, far from raw materials and customers. They manufacture goods so outmoded that only desperate Soviet consumers would buy them. There has been no change in economic ties since the Baltic republic voted to secede. Relations with the Soviet Union are critical for Lithuania, which gets all its oil and gas from Siberia at low rates. Moscow needs Lithuania, whose factories produce parts for Soviet plants. A Lithuanian parliamentary commission on independence said the republic has plenty of electric power, including a nuclear plant at Ignalina that can provide virtually all its needs. But supplies of oil, gas, important raw materials, repair parts, fertilizer and communications could be cut off, the commission said. ``The hands are on the faucets, but they haven't been turned,'' said Lawrence Summers, a Harvard University economics professor and one of the experts Kazickas has helped to bring over as an adviser on economic reform. Lithuania and its sister Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia, have drawn up complete economic reform plans. Their people generally appear willing to accept higher prices and unemployment as part of the parcel. All three Baltic republics were part of the Russian empire from the late 18th century until after World War I. They were independent between the wars but forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 after Moscow took control of the republics under terms of the secret Hitler-Stalin pact. Independence in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia coincided with some of the Soviet Union's most ruinous years, in the 1920s and 1930s. The Baltic republics' roads, buildings, and communications generally are in far better repair than those of the Soviet Union, evidence of greater efficiency and their period of independence. There are three freeways in Lithuania; in other Soviet republics many villages have no road at all. But virtually all communications go through Soviet territory, so the Lithuanians have begun negotiations with Poland for a new direct connection to the West. Among proposed economic reforms, Summers has recommended allowing prices to rise on non-essential items to encourage manufacture of goods in extremely short supply and soak up excess Soviet rubles. He said Lithuania should introduce its own currency in 1991, freely convertible at a low exchange rate. Summers said low currency exchange rates could make labor costs in the new Lithuania attractive to nearby, high-wage Scandanavia, but for now Lithuania remains inefficient. Many Soviets scoff at the aspirations for independence in the Baltics, contending the tiny republics could not survive on their own. Balts invite skeptics to look at Finland. Fifty years ago, Finland and the Baltics had similar economies and incomes. Finland's climate is harsher and it has few natural resources, yet it fought a war to remain independent of the Soviets and has developed a thriving economy. Today, Finland's per capita income is more than quadruple that of the Soviet Union. Lithuanian economist Valdas Terleckas said his country had a 10 percent annual growth rate in its 22 years as an independent, capitalist nation. That is higher than most countries in the world today. In response to such statistics, the Soviet press has cited diplomatic dispatches from the Baltic republics during independence that spoke of economic decay and widespread unemployment. The republic's new government has moved to stop strangling business by cutting the number of ministries from an already-reduced 40 to 18. The Soviet bureaucracy, blamed for stalling Gorbachev's reforms, still has 48 ministries and 28 commissions. Independence will force the Vilnius Electrical Measuring Device Factory to redesign its product line, primarily household electric meters, so it can produce goods efficiently and compete outside the Soviet Union, Cuba, and Africa, said plant director Vincas Babilius. He is thrilled with the prospect, because ``I want to be a free man. I want to deal with whomever I want, to set my own prices, and decide what to do with my own profits.'' Violinist Rimas Cekuolis expressed what most Lithuanians seemed to feel: ``It's not important whether our life is better or worse. Freedom is what is important.''

DOC.HEAD: Qatar Frees 57 Prisoners to Mark Ramadan
DOC.TEXT: The emir of Qatar, Sheik Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani, on Sunday ordered that 57 prisoners be freed to mark the holy month of Ramadan, the official Qatar News Agency reported. It is customary for leaders of Islamic countries to release prisoners in honor of Moslem holidays. The world's 1 billion Moslems fast from dawn to dusk during Ramadan. The three-day Eid al-Fitr feast that marks the end of the holiday is expected to fall this year around April 26, depending when the new moon is sighted. Earlier this month, 364 prisoners were freed in the United Arab Emirates to mark Ramadan.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Committees Ignoring Moynihan, Rostenkowski Plans
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate budget committees are moving toward adoption of fiscal 1991 deficit-reduction plans that ignore eye-catching proposals by two of Congress's most influential members. The Democratic chairmen of the two panels, which are well behind schedule, hope to produce separate $1.2-trillion spending blueprints for next year by late this month. But neither will reflect Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan to cut the Social Security payroll tax or Rep. Dan Rostenkowski's call for a combination of widespread spending cuts and tax hikes. Instead, House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., and his Senate counterpart, James Sasser, D-Tenn., are prodding their Democrat-dominated committees to compose similar packages that rely on more traditional formulas. Plans considered likely to emerge from each budget panel would shrink the deficit by $37 billion, relying on roughly equal amounts of defense cuts and new taxes and lesser savings from cuts in Medicare, payments to farmers and other domestic programs. ``I'll be able to get a budget resolution out of committee,'' Panetta said last week after two weeks of closed-door meetings with panel members. ``It will take a lot of work on the (House) floor, but we will pass it there, too.'' The decisions to snub Moynihan, D-N.Y., and Rostenkowski, D-Ill., reflect different judgments. Congressional leaders believe Rostenkowski's proposal to save $55 billion next year by freezing Social Security and other domestic programs and by raising income taxes and other levies is medicine that is simply too harsh for most lawmakers. ``There are no votes there,'' Panetta said of the plan advanced by the chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee. ``Rostenkowski would have much greater impact if there were votes there to support it.'' Moynihan's proposal is aimed at driving down the Social Security surplus, which the senator _ considered Congress's expert on the retirement system _ complains makes the overall budget deficit look smaller. But his proposal to slash the payroll tax would shrink federal revenues by $55 billion, a cut that members of Moynihan's own party complain would make next year's anticipated $101 billion federal shortfall even larger. The Gramm-Rudman Act sets a deficit target of $64 billion for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. ``We're going to have enough difficulty meeting the budget targets without coming up at this juncture with a revenue loser,'' Sasser said. For their parts, Moynihan and Rostenkowski insist that their proposals are still alive. Moynihan said last week that he expects a Senate vote on his plan in May and that he expects to win. Rostenkowski said he believes his proposal stands as good a chance as anything Panetta can piece together. Panetta's and Sasser's committees will begin writing their budget plans in earnest when Congress returns from its Easter recess next week. So far, Panetta is considering a plan that would hold defense spending to about $295 billion _ $11.5 billion below the amount needed to keep up with inflation, and $8 billion less than President Bush wants. He would raise $14 billion in new, minor taxes _ the same amount as Bush. He also would cut Medicare and other federal benefit programs by $3.5 billion, while boosting housing, childrens' and other social programs by about $6 billion. Sasser wants his committee to compress military spending to about $292 billion. He also would collect $14 billion in new taxes, while seeking savings in some domestic programs. Republicans from both panels say they will oppose the Democratic packages. Senate GOP budget-writers say they may offer their own proposals, while House Republicans say they will support the budget Bush proposed in January. ``He's our big brother and he's going to do the fist-fighting for us,'' Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House budget panel, said of Bush. By law, Congress is supposed to finish the budget by April 15, a deadline that is routinely ignored. The compromise House-Senate plan that Congress finally adopts sets guidelines that must be followed by separate tax and spending bills, which will be written later in the year.

DOC.HEAD: A Week After Rioting, Britain Seeks Explanation for Violence
DOC.TEXT: As one editorial summed it up: The Conservatives blamed the Labor Party, which blamed the militant left, which blamed the anarchists, who accepted the charge with pride. The comment, in the left-wing weekly New Statesman and Society, was one of many attempting to explain rioting that tore through the heart of London a week ago. The violence came the day before local property taxes were replaced with a per-capita ``community charge.'' ``A `community charge' means running full pelt down a street with a brick in your hand and a `pig' in your sights,'' said the newspaper Class War, published by an anarchist group with the same name. Was it organized or spontaneous? Should police share the blame? Did it expose an underclass that has grown up feeling left out of the ``property-owning democracy'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher dreams of creating? The occasion was a March 31 march by 40,000 people protesting the new tax. Police say about 3,000 attacked officers, smashed shop windows, looted and started fires. They said 374 officers and 86 civilians were injured, and 339 arrests were made. Trouble apparently started when mounted police moved a small group of unruly demonstrators away from Downing Street, where Mrs. Thatcher lives, into Trafalgar Square. Peaceful protesters in the square thought police were attacking the crowd, witnesses said. Peter Taaffe, general secretary of Militant Tendency, a radical left-wing movement, said: ``The police action infuriated the crowd, including some Militant supporters who oppose violence. It ignited an explosion. ``Many of these young people are very angry. They are unemployed, harassed and have an accumulated hatred of the police,'' he said. ``All that fury came to the fore and they began attacking any symbol of society. That included the police, and the obscene display of wealth in the West End which is cheek by jowl with desolate poverty.'' Dr. Jock Young, a sociologist at Middlesex Polytechnic, said animosity must have been widespread for the anarchist groups to have had an effect. ``The young people are living in a very affluent society,'' he said. ``It is the relative deprivation which creates the disaffected and starts to create cultures of violence, particularly among young men. ``Football is one expression of this. It provides a vehicle for young machismo blokes to get together in large numbers and let off a lot of steam.'' Phil Kelly, editor of the left-wing weekly Tribune, said anarchism attracts the alienated. ``Their whole contact with authority is unpleasant,'' Kelly said. ``They are living in illegal squats or derelict buildings. The only contact they have with the police is when they get stopped because of the way they look.'' Rioters faced the wrath of the entire political establishment. The Labor Party condemned them as vociferously as Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives. Labor was to blame, the Tories said, because a minority of its members of Parliament advocates breaking the law by refusing to pay the so-called poll tax. Many of those brought before magistrates were age 17 to 30 and gave their addresses as squatter apartments or buildings. Others were what are still known in Britain as hippies, living nomadic lives in the backs of vans. Violence breaks out in all sorts of contexts in Britain. Anarchists make periodic charges through the City, London's financial district, smashing bank windows and other symbols of capitalism. Droves of hippies converge on Stonehenge in June to celebrate the summer solstice, and battle police who try to keep them from the protected national monument. Animal rights campaigners disrupt foxhunts. England's soccer hooligans, who caused 39 deaths in a rampage at a Brussels stadium in 1985, are feared continent-wide. ``Every generation has had its disruptive element, and our disruptive element is probably the anarchists,'' said sociologist Norman Jones. ``The glorious days when there was no violence is a misconceived idea.'' Dr. D.B. O'Leary at the London School of Economics said it is wrong to assume Britain was on the verge of rampant anarchism. ``You have to look at the interaction of a very hot day, incompetent policing and the fact that many people wanted a scrap if the occasion was offered to them _ and it was,'' he said. Young, of Middlesex Polytechnic, considers Britain still a relatively non-violent country, not much different from other parts of Europe and with one-tenth the U.S. murder rate. But some language heard and read since the riot has been violent. New Statesman and Society carried an article by a 25-year-old Londoner identified only as Tony, who said he threw rocks at police during the riot. Tony wrote: ``The police won't come to terms with the fact that they're distrusted and hated. It wasn't even about the poll tax; that was just the occasion for it. It was a young people's riot, a spontaneous outburst by people from all over the country. That's what made it so great. I did what I did because I could.'' ``The police were attacked and quite rightly so,'' said Andy Murphy, a 28-year-old anarchist who works for the London borough of Hackney.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Break Ground for `Peace Village' on Site of Vietnam War Landing
LaserPhoto BK1
DOC.TEXT: Ten Americans returned to a Vietnamese beach where U.S. forces landed 25 years ago, and laid the foundation for a ``Peace Village'' to assist victims of the Vietnam War, a participant said Sunday. Gordon Smith, a Vietnam War veteran, said he and nine other Americans laid the cornerstones for the ``village'' on China Beach. Plans call for a rehabilitation center, orphanage, a medical center and trade school. The ground-breaking ceremony, also attended by Vietnamese Red Cross officials, took place March 26. On March 8, 1965, more than 3,500 Marines stormed onto the beach near the central Vietnam city of Danang in a major escalation of the war. The project is led by Le Ly Hayslip, who initially collaborated with the Communist Viet Cong as a teen-ager. After a series of harrowing wartime experiences, she married an American and came to the United States. Her autobiography, ``When Heaven and Earth Changed Places,'' was published in the United States last year. Ms. Hayslip's East Meets West Foundation has in recent years provided medical assistance to Vietnam through private funding, including contributions from Oliver Stone, the Vietnam veteran who has directed two major films on Vietnam, ``Platoon'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' Ms. Hayslip, who lives in Escondido, Calif., was born in a small village near Danang. Smith, of Monterey, Calif., said additional fund raising in the United States would be necessary before construction of the village could begin. The center would help the handicapped who fought on both sides in the war, victims of land mines that continue to take their toll on civilians, and people suffering from ailments unrelated to the war, he said. The China Beach project is one of a growing number of private American efforts to heal the wounds of the Vietnam War. These have frequently been initiated by war veterans. The United States does not recognize the Hanoi government and forbids commerce with Vietnam. American aid organizations must obtain permits from Washington and operate under certain financial restrictions in Vietnam. Smith was involved in the building of a medical clinic by war veterans in the southern seaside town of Vung Tau. The clinic opened March 30, 1989, and receives medical supplies obtained by veterans in the United States. Smith, who is involved in Hayslip's group and a number of veterans organizations, said he hoped to start a program to send American nurses who served in the war to the clinic and Vung Tau hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Not Alone in Saving Less
DOC.TEXT: Americans often are blamed for having lost the old Yankee love of thrift, but the International Monetary Fund has found that people in some other developed countries are saving even less. It predicted the trend will continue as the world's population ages. Older people have less to save for. ``The negative trend in national saving rates experienced by all the major industrial countries since the early to mid-1970s has raised serious concerns about the prospects for strong and sustainable growth in the world economy,'' said the latest issue of the semiweekly ``IMF Survey.'' The scolding is based on a report by a team under Bijan B. Aghelvi, senior advisor in the fund's research department at its headquarters in Washington. When people put money into their bank accounts, the banks lend it out to industry for building the factories that will produce more goods and jobs in the future. If savings are too small, industry has to borrow from other countries. Governments also save -- or, more often, ``dis-save'' by going further into debt. When a government spends more than it collects in taxes, it has to borrow from the savings of its citizens or from other countries. Its taxpayers then have to pay interest on the debt. The United States is a prime example on both counts. Americans of the future will have to pay interest to other countries on the billions being borrowed by Americans today. According to the most recent figures from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in Paris, the average American household in 1988 saved only $4.40 out of every $100 of after-tax income. But Americans were far from being the biggest spendthrifts. The average Swedish household did not save at all. It drew on past savings or went into debt at the rate of $3.60 dollars for every $100 dollars earned. The average Norwegian family had ``dis-savings'' of $1.20 per $100 of income and families in Finland spent an average $101.40 for every $100 earned. Of the major industrial countries, the Japanese were the top savers: $15.20 dollars out of $100 of income. But even the thrifty Japanese have loosened up _ in 1976, they saved $23.20 of every $100 earned. The average West German family in 1988 saved $12.60 of every $100 earned, down from $15.10 in 1975. Dutch families in 1988 saved only $2 of every $100 of income. Another IMF-sponsored study warns that a country's capital will be consumed unless money is set aside to replace it, and more must be put aside as the population grows. ``High rates of saving in the Federal Republic of Germany and Japan in particular... have contributed to rapid rises in the standard of living,'' wrote Roger S. Smith, who teaches economics at the University of Alberta, in Canada. ``(South) Korea, Singapore and Taiwan... are clear current examples that high saving rates go hand in hand with rapid economic growth.'' Smith wrote that government deficits have reduced savings in a number of countries. ``Belgium, Canada, Italy and the United States may be the most obvious examples, but Australia, the Netherlands, Sweden and the United Kingdom also have had significant public sector deficits during the 1980s,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Eyes Sale of Supercomputer to India, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: After months of delay, the United States has decided in principle to sell a supercomputer to India, sources say, despite warnings that it could be used to make nuclear weapons or ballistic missiles. But granting an export license for the sophisticated Cray computer depends on India's willingness to adopt measures restricting its use to peaceful research and preventing the transfer of its data to unauthorized parties, said one source. The sources, discussing the prospective deal on condition of anonymity, said Indian was balking at the conditions, noting that a supercomputer bought in 1987 was being used only to forecast monsoons. Indian officials also are pointing out that the country signed a 1984 agreement promising not to transfer high-tech equipment to other nations, the sources added. The decision to approve the sale in principle reflects the U.S. government's ambivalence about exporting state-of-the-art computers to countries with nuclear capabilities. Decisions about the sale of similar computers to Israel and Brazil have been stalled for as long as two years, with the Department of Energy and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency lobbying against the deals, said one source. The Cray computer is destined for the Institute of Science of Bangalore, India, which conducts biotechnological and other research, said Indian officials. Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, said the institute also studies stress on rocket bodies. Milhollin, whose organization tracks the spread of nuclear weapons to developing countries, said India could apply the supercomputer data to missile development. The Commerce Department, which takes the lead in granting or denying export licenses, refused to comment. But last week the department announced it had fined a West German company $800,000 for exporting nuclear material to India and several other countries. In general, the Bush administration is easing controls over the export of supercomputers, partly because of growing pressure from manufacturers stung by government budget cuts and partly because of a relaxation in technology exports to formerly communist governments. The Commerce Department is pruning and streamlining the lists of high-tech items banned for export to Eastern Europe. And NATO has been pressing the United States to speed up the process. In addition, the Commerce Department is redefining which supercomputers must receive special export licenses requiring a safeguard plan. Under the proposed definition, countries buying supercomputers with a capability of up to 150 megaflops _ a measure of computing speed _ would not be required to adopt a safeguards plan. The previous limit was 100 megaflops. Proponents of the sales argue that countries determined to produce nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles can do so without supercomputers, especially since the new generation of desktop computers are so powerful they can compute as fast. They note that supercomputers are put to many beneficial uses, including weather predictions, seismic analysis and medical and scientific research. Opponents argue that the fast-computing machines make it much easier to design weapons, especially because of their ability to simulate and analyze the effects of nuclear explosions and missile flights. They also note that Brazil, India and Israel have not signed the International Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty although all have nuclear capabilities or are near having them. That means their nuclear facilities are not inspected by outsiders. Pressure from the industry is fierce, especially in the face of sharp competition from Japan _ the only other country that makes such machines. U.S. exports of supercomputers were valued at $400 million in 1989 and are projected to double this year. Japan's 1990 exports are expected to reach $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Obit-White Bjt
Bush Mourns Boy's Death
DOC.TEXT: President Bush mourned the death AIDS sufferer Ryan White Sunday, saying Americans must continue fighting against the deadly immune system disease. ``Barbara and I are deeply saddened with the death of Ryan White,'' Bush said in a statement released a few hours after the 18-year-old Indiana youth died in a hospital in Indianapolis. ``All Americans are impressed by his courage, strength and his ability to continue fighting,'' the president said. ``Ryan's death reaffirms that we as a people must pledge to continue the fight, his fight against this dreaded disease.'' ``We send our condolences to his family and will keep them in our hearts and prayers,'' the statement said. Last week, Bush planted a tree in Indianapolis in honor of White. White was diagnosed as having AIDS in December 1984 when he was 13. He contracted acquired immune deficiency syndrome through a blood-clotting agent used to treat his hemophilia. White gained national attention when he was barred from Western Middle School near Kokomo, Ind., after school officials and parents there rejected health authorities' reassurances that AIDS could not be spread through casual contact with those infected. Later, he moved to Cicero, Ind., where he attended school.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary's Election Runoff at a Glance
With AM-Hungary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a look at Sunday's second round of national elections in Hungary.
POLLING: Polls opened at 6 a.m. and closed at 6 p.m. More than 7.5 million people were eligible to vote, all those 18 years or older or considered adults by marriage.

AT STAKE: _261 seats in the parliament, or National Assembly, to be filled for a four-year term, with eight other seats to be allocated to representatives of Hungary's eight national minorities. _Mandate to run the government or form a coalition.

RESULTS OF FIRST ROUND: On March 25, candidates from 29 political parties competed for 394 seats in the National Assembly. In the voting 176 seats were to be chosen by direct elections, 210 according to the proportion of the vote received by each party, and eight seats were reserved for national minorities. In the first round of voting, only five candidates won a mandate in the direct elections. Victory requires a majority in the vote. Of the 210 seats assigned by proportional vote, 120 were decided on March 25. A further 90 seats will be divided up among the parties after the runoff according to a complex mathematical formula on the basis of national aggregate votes won. Only parties that received at least 4 percent of the vote in the first round are eligible.

MAIN PARTIES RUNNING: Only six of 29 parties that competed in the first round cleared the 4 percent hurdle qualifying them for Sunday's runoff. They are: _Hungarian Democratic Forum, which won 24.73 percent of the March 25 vote, took 40 of the party slate seats and fielded 159 candidates in Sunday's runoff. _League of Free Democrats 21.39 percent; 34 seats; 150 candidates. _Independent Smallholders' Party 11.73 percent; 16 seats; 76 candidates. _Hungarian Socialist Party 10.89 percent; 14 seats; 54 candidates. _League of Young Democrats 8.95 percent; 8 seats; 8 candidates. _Christian Democratic People's Party 6.46 percent; 8 seats; 20 candidates.

ISSUES: The No. 1 issue was which party or what sort of coalition will govern the country after 43 years of Communist rule. The first priority of any new government will be to energize Hungary's sagging economy.

ELECTION SUPERVISION: The Vienna-based International Helsinki Human Rights Association, the Strassbourg-based Council of Europe, and members of an international delegation sponsored by the U.S. Democratic and Republican parties.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Devastates a Blue Nile Village
DOC.TEXT: A fire in a village in the central Blue Nile region killed four people and left more than 500 families homeless, the state-run Sudan News Agency said Sunday. A woman and three children were killed when the fire raged through Bott, a village of 2,500 people, the report said. The blaze destroyed the families' homes, burned the local market and killed scores of domestic animals, the news agency said. It did not say when the fire broke out or how it started.

DOC.HEAD: Bus-Truck Crash Kills 13, Injures 6 in Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: A minibus collided with a truck on the ancient Grand Trunk Road outside Islamabad on Sunday, killing 13 people and injuring six, police said. All the casualties were traveling in the bus; the driver of the truck fled the scene, according to Pakistan's official news agency. The Grand Trunk Road links Pakistan's border city of Peshawar to India's teeming western city of Calcutta. It was made famous in the West by author Rudyard Kipling, whose protagonist in the book ``Kim'' wandered through India on the Grand Trunk. Today, many cars travel the road at break-neck speeds, swerving around horse-drawn carts, bicycles and motorized rickshaws. Overcrowded buses, with passengers hanging off the roof and out the windows, are often the worst of the speeding offenders.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 100 Countries At Drug Conference
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 countries begin an anti-drug conference Monday that focuses on education and other measures aimed at cutting demand especially for cocaine, which has begun to hit Europe hard, officials say. ``We know in the end as long as demand is there, there will always be somebody to get the supply through,'' said Home Office Minister David Mellor, one of Britain's top law enforcement officials. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia and U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will address the opening of the World Ministerial Drugs Summit at the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Center opposite Westminster Abbey. Mellor called Barco as ``a courageous representative of a drug nation struggling against drug traffickers,'' who have killed more than 200 people in their 7-month-old war with the Colombian government. Britain has invited all members of the United Nations and all non-member observer states to the three-day conference. Lynda Chalker, minister of overseas development, said her government is paying the expenses of delegations from some developing countries. The conference, organized by the British government in association with the United Nations, follows up the International Conference on Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking held in Vienna in June 1987. That conference agreed for the first time on an overall approach focusing on prevention, treatment, rehabilitation and reducing supplies. This week's summit will consider education programs to prevent drug use, identification of drug misusers and early intervention to prevent misuse, and emerging issues in the development of demand reduction policies including AIDS. Organizers decided to single out cocaine, Mellor said, because ``cocaine has suddenly come from nowhere to be the principle drug of misuse, not only here but elsewhere in the world.'' ``The American experience shows that we underestimate cocaine at our peril, especially when mixed with smoking as crack,'' he said. While cocaine has been confined mainly to the Western hemisphere, organizers said they decided to include it in the conference because there was strong evidence that the cocaine cartels are looking for new markets in Europe and other regions. In the past three years the amount of cocaine seized in the 12 European Economic Community states has tripled to more than five tons last year. In 1988, British authorities for the first time seized more cocaine than heroin. The conference will examine the entire cycle from cultivation of the coca bush to the disposal of the proceeds of street sales of cocaine and crack. Mellor said Britain's concern was that there should be ``a practical outcome'' of the conference _ added impetus for drug-fighting institutions, adoption of a research program and agreement on enhanced international cooperation.

DOC.HEAD: Astronomers Jittery About Woes That Might Trouble the Hubble
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: As the Hubble Space Telescope awaits a ride into space, scientists remain jittery about the many things that could go wrong with NASA's costliest satellite _ from a fogged mirror to space junk. ``It's hitting us in our guts,'' said Ed Weiler, Hubble program scientist at the agency's Washington headquarters. ``We're all having dreams about this thing. We're reliving meetings on what could go wrong, and we're wondering, `Did we make a mistake somewhere?''' Getting the $1.5 billion telescope ready to be placed in orbit by the shuttle Discovery this week _ after seven years of delay _ has ``been one big pain in the rear, but it's going to be worth every minute every one of us spent on it,'' he said. Because the unmanned telescope will peer farther into space than any other observatory, ``we know we are going to discover things that are totally unexpected, that our human imaginations can't even envision.'' Potential woes facing Hubble include equipment failures, contamination of its sensitive mirror and light detectors, dependence for repairs on an overburdened shuttle fleet, and sunspot activity that might drag the telescope from its proper orbit. ``We have plenty of concerns and plenty of areas we know need improvement, but we have no showstoppers,'' said David R. Skillman, a chief telescope engineer at Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. ``I fully expect this thing will be operating for 20 or 30 years'' _ well beyond the planned 15-year mission. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to put Hubble in orbit 380 miles above the Earth, higher than any shuttle has flown. Discovery is scheduled for launch Tuesday. But if one of Discovery's three engines doesn't produce full power or fails completely after launch _ as happened to Challenger in July 1985 _ the shuttle wouldn't reach an adequate altitude. The astronauts would either bring the telescope back or put it in a lower orbit until a shuttle could tow it higher. As long as Hubble is deployed at least 326 miles above Earth, it can make some useful observations for a year before it needs a boost, flight director William Reeves said. Shuttle maintenance flights every three years will tow the telescope back up to 380 miles if its orbit decays because of sunspots. The current solar cycle is the second most intense on record, spewing solar wind that heats and inflates Earth's atmosphere, increasing friction that can make satellites fall from orbit more quickly. If the shuttle fleet were grounded for years by another tragedy like the Challenger explosion, the telescope could burn up in the atmosphere. Astronaut-astronomer Steve Hawley said vibration during Discovery's ascent is unlikely to damage the telescope's mirror, but ``if it sat on the pad for a long time, you might worry about possible contamination.'' That's because the shuttle's cargo bay is not as clean as either the vacuum of space or the ``clean room'' where the telescope was readied for flight, said Mark Johnston of the Baltimore-based Space Telescope Science Institute, which schedules use of telescope time. Installation of the Hubble into the shuttle's cargo bay was delayed briefly last month after insects invaded the clean room. NASA officials believe they can deal with all conceivable troubles except the possibility the Hubble might be obliterated by a speeding meteoroid or a hunk of junk from some previous space flight. A study of Air Force space junk statistics concluded that there is a 1 percent chance that that a fragment large enough to destroy the telescope _ 4 inches wide _ would hit it during its 15-year mission, Johnston said. The telescope is aimed with internal gyroscopes, but lacks thrusters to maneuver it away from an impending collision. Weiler disputed the 1 percent estimate as exaggerated, so ``I'm not going to lose sleep over it.'' Because the launch has been delayed so long, much of the telescope's equipment is aging and some might fail, including electrical connections and moving parts such as camera shutters and filter wheels, Johnston said. Hubble is designed ``so that as parts fail, other parts can be turned on to replace them,'' Skillman said. If a malfunction seriously threatens the telescope, NASA is committed to launching a shuttle within a year instead of waiting for a regular maintenance mission. But ``if I were a Hubble Space Telescope project guy, I would always carry with me a lingering concern that when I need the support, is it going to be available to me?'' Hawley said. When shuttles approach on servicing missions, thrust exhaust might fog Hubble's mirror, but Skillman said that can be prevented with careful maneuvering. While Hubble's orbit makes it accessible for repairs, it also leaves the telescope able to make observations only 35 percent of each day, Johnston said. Earth will block desired targets 40 percent of the time. The telescope needs 10 percent of its time to locate and lock onto ``guide stars'' so it remains steady. It is unusable 15 percent of the time when it passes east of Brazil, where orbiting radiation belts dip low enough to interfere with the telescope's electronics.

DOC.HEAD: Police Recover Stolen Mosaic, Arrest Suspects
DOC.TEXT: Police recovered a 1,200-year-old mosaic in a raid near the capital and arrested three mosaic dealers accused of ripping the artwork out of the floor of an ancient desert castle a week ago, authorities said Sunday. Police on Saturday arrested a man and his two sons and found the artwork at their home in the ancient Roman city of Jerash, 22 miles north of Amman, a police spokesman said. The 15-by-18-foot mosaic was the most intact early Islamic mosaic in Jordan before it was stolen, ``but obviously the gang dropped it somewhere while they were hurrying to leave the castle,'' said Ghazi Bisheh, antiquities director of the Tourism Ministry. The mosaic with a ``tree of life'' design was taken from Hallabat Castle, a Roman and Moslem fortress 30 miles northeast of Amman. The theft prompted demands for better protection of the fort, which was guarded by a nearby Bedouin villager. Minister of Tourism Abdul-Karim Kabariti said last week the thieves apparently took advantage of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan to enter the site at dusk, when the guard, like most Moslems, was breaking his dawn-to-dusk fast with a meal. The police official said Saleh Issa Suleiman, 51, and his two sons, 32-year-old Mohammed and 28-year-old Ahmad, were charged with stealing antiquities. The official, who cannot be identified under police regulations, said conviction could bring one to three years in prison and a minimum fine of $500. He said harsher measures are expected against the gang for ruining such a precious antiquity. The design was also almost ruined due to the rough way it was lifted off the floor, Bisheh said. The thieves ``applied strong glue to the surface of the mosaic, covered it with a large jute cloth and carelessly lifted the entire picture off the floor at one time.'' ``We will be able to fix it, since we have all the necessary documents and picture of the design,'' Bisheh said. ``But we will now put it in a safer place, the Jerash Museum.'' Bisheh said the multicolor design, depicting a large tree surrounded by lions, bulls, goats and birds, was created in the eighth century when the fortress was used as a hunting outpost by early Islamic rulers. The castle was one of several in the Jordanian and Syrian deserts used as Roman outposts in the second and third centuries. Archaeologists say it was used as a monastery in the seventh century before it was taken over the the Ummayed Moslems in the years after the Islamic conquest.

DOC.HEAD: Western Investors Race to Get Foot in Emerging East German Market
DOC.TEXT: Dieter Kloss grinned as yet another group of Western businessmen with bulging briefcases crammed the lobby of the modest but busy offices of the East German Chamber of Foreign Trade. ``I'm having a great time at work these days. Only six months ago such coming and going would have been unthinkable,'' said Kloss, an economist. The chamber is advising growing numbers of American, West European, and Asian businesses trying to get a foot in East Germany before the market is saturated. Before the dramatic opening of the country's borders and the collapse of Communist rule last fall, most of the chamber's visitors came from the East bloc trading alliance COMECON. ``Western firms began coming from day one of the changes and we're encouraging them partly because we're feeling a bit overrun by West Germany,'' Kloss said. Signs of the arrival of foreign firms are spreading across East Berlin. Almost daily, workmen at the International Trade Center climb up a high ladder in the lobby to letter the names of new companies that have leased office space in the downtown skyscraper. Levi Strauss recently mounted its red logo on the door of a 15th floor suite from which the company will run future operations in East Germany, where Western jeans are already a hit. Coca Cola began selling soda in East Germany two months ago and its West German subsidiary is now seeking an East German partner to start a production plant. Both Levi Strauss and Coca Cola were sold previously in East Germany, but only in hard-currency Intershops for foreigners. Price Waterhouse Inc., the U.S. financial services firm, is setting up in East Berlin, as is the prestigious investment bank, Salomon Brothers Inc. ``If you want to be part of East German developments you have to have a presence there,'' said Peter Coym, Managing Director of Salomon Brothers' operations in West Germany. The bank plans to open its office in the sumptuous Grand Hotel in East Berlin in mid-April, with a focus on investment banking and consulting connected to the privatization of state companies. The computer giant IBM plans a joint venture with the East German firm Robotron, while General Motors-Opel beat out West German giants Daimler-Benz and BMW to hook up with the Wartburg car plant. Caterpillar has started marketing tractors, backloaders and other agricultural and building machines through its West German subsidiary, Zeppelin. ``There is great demand in East Germany. Their machines are old and outmoded. Everybody is interested in getting a foot in East Germany,'' said Hans Knausel, a spokesman for Zeppelin. It didn't used to be that way. For four decades, the Communist governments and complicated centralized economies discouraged Western businessmen from trying to trade with East Germany. Trade with the United States in 1989 amounted to about $200 million, turnover with France was under $2 billion, and there was almost no business at all with South Korea. Western organizations that encouraged business in West Berlin, an outpost of democracy during the Cold War, must now start thinking of Berlin as a whole. The American Chamber of Commerce is considering a move from West to East Berlin, where its offices were located before World War II. The Berlin Economic Development Corporation founded in 1978 with the task of attracting outside investment to West Berlin is also now looking eastward. ``Recently we expanded our activities in the eastern direction. Companies who come to us for advice are more interested in East Berlin,'' said Helmut Wolf, who advises English-speaking companies. Other West European and Asian countries have joined the United States in the race to penetrate the East German market, swamped by West German firms seeking partners. The Italian carmaker FIAT has announced plans to produce cars in East Germany. The French and British want to develop hotels, but have been less aggressive than the Americans or the Italians. Kloss said East Germany had just signed an agreement on economic cooperation with South Korea that could offer expertise in the steel and shipbuilding sectors. Despite the changes, there are still barriers to developing trade in East Germany. Western companies still cannot convert profits into hard currency and send them home, and some companies are unwilling to invest until the German currencies are merged, probably this summer. But other companies say now is the time to enter the market and earn name recognition even though East German marks are almost worthless.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Invites World Youth to Join Him in Poland
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday invited youths from around the world to join him at Poland's most famous Roman Catholic shrine in August 1991 to mark World Youth Day. The pope's statement, at the conclusion of a Palm Sunday Mass, was his first confirmation of a 1991 trip to Poland. Polish church officials have said they expected a visit, the fourth by John Paul to his homeland since he became pope in 1978. The pope's announcement came as the Vatican is intensifying its activities in the newly democratic countries of Eastern Europe after decades of oppression from Communist governments. The Vatican on Sunday offered to mediate in the dispute over independence between Lithuania and the Soviet Union. The youth rally will likely bring tens of thousands of youths from around the world to Czestochowa, whose icon has symbolized Polish nationalism and religious faith during centuries of foreign occupation and partition. The pope said the Madonna of Czestochowa, honored at the shrine in southern Poland, ``has constituted the heart of the history of the Polish people for more than 600 years.'' John Paul said the theme of the youth day would be the Gospel phrase ``You have received the spirit of children.'' ``In the era in which we are living, marked by profound social upheavals, this spirit of children of God constitutes the true propulsive element of the history of peoples and the life of individuals,'' the pontiff said in Italian to more than 20,000 people in front of St. Peter's Basilica. The pope has previously marked the church's World Youth Day with international rallies in Buenos Aires, Argentina in 1987 and in Santiago de Compostela, Spain, in August. According to legend, the ``Black Madonna'' of Czestochowa was painted by St. Luke on a plank of wood from Christ's table. John Paul is particularly devoted to the shrine, which he has visited on his previous papal trips to Poland in 1979, 1983 and 1987. The pope's trip will be his first to Poland since the Communist regime gave way to a government dominated by the labor movement, Solidarity, which John Paul has strongly supported. The Italian news agency ANSA, without citing sources, said the pontiff's trip might be divided in two parts: a visit in June to Warsaw and other cities, and a trip to Czestochowa in August. The church established its World Youth Day in 1986 and celebrates it in alternate years in Rome. Sunday's Mass marked the 1990 World Youth Day, as well as Palm Sunday. John Paul, wearing red robes, blessed palms symbolizing the holy day during the open-air Mass, which commemorated Jesus Christ's triumphant entry into Jerusalem. At the end of the ceremony, he offered greetings to youths in several languages. Holy Week services continue later this week when the pope re-enacts part of Christ's last supper with his apostles on Holy Thursday. The pope plans to carry a wooden cross in a Good Friday procession at the Colosseum. He celebrates an Easter vigil Saturday night and Mass at St. Peter's on Easter Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Supreme Court Justices Pan Lawyers' Performances
DOC.TEXT: Two Supreme Court justices, the most junior and the most senior, give low grades to the lawyers who have appeared before them this year. Too many lawyers misunderstand the purpose of the high court's argument sessions, both say. ``I'm really surprised,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said in a recent interview. ``They don't understand that a good oral argument is really like a discussion of the doctoral thesis, not a debate. It's relaxed, in a sense. It's a quiet inquiry, not a pyrotechnic performance.'' Kennedy, who joined the court in 1988, says the quality of advocacy during oral arguments ``has not been as good this year as last.'' Justice William J. Brennan, who has been listening to high court arguments since 1956, agrees. When asked if many lawyers misconstrue what is expected of them at the arguments, Brennan said, ``I'm very sure that's true, and I don't know whose fault that is.'' Of the some 5,000 cases that reach the court each year, the justices grant review to about 150 cases. In those, lawyers for each side appear before the nine justices for an hour-long argument session _ the only work the court performs in public _ before a decision is reached. Brennan recalled during a recent interview that as a state appellate judge in New Jersey he thought ``the level of advocacy was appalling.'' ``When appointed to this court, I thought, `My gosh, when I get to the Supreme Court of the United States, immediately there's going to be a marked increase in quality.' Well, I haven't found that all these years,'' he said. Brennan said he believes the general demise in quality this year even has infected the Justice Department lawyers who represent the federal government before the high court. After noting that the solicitor general's small staff usually offers the government ``first-rate representation,'' Brennan said, ``And yet, I'm not so sure that's true this year. I don't know why. They still have very, very bright young people. Perhaps they just haven't been at it long enough.'' Some courts, streamlining due to heavy caseloads, have eliminated argument sessions, and make their decisions based on written briefs alone. Brennan hopes the Supreme Court never takes that course. ``Oral argument is one of the most important of our procedures. I often get different ideas during oral arguments resulting in changes'' of how he views a case, he said. But Brennan, the court's leading liberal, rarely asks any questions during the sessions _ unlike Kennedy and the other relatively young conservative justices. ``In past years, I guess I asked as many questions as those of my colleagues today who ask most questions,'' Brennan said. ``I have discovered that I get the most out of oral arguments if I let the lawyers ... present their cases uninterrupted by me.'' He added: ``That seems to have worked ... I get everything I want out of the oral arguments.'' Kennedy takes another approach. ``I ask questions for a couple of reasons,'' he said. ``To let counsel know my concerns, and to let my colleagues know my concerns.'' Kennedy was surprised when told that many visitors to the courtroom sessions have mentioned his stern judicial scowl. ``It may be that I value oral argument so highly that I'm very anxious for the attorney to perform at his best,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Flutist James Galway's eyes sparkle at the mention of his operatic debut in the title role of Rossini's ``The Thieving Magpie'' in its first U.S. performance in this century. ``I didn't study birds for years to do this. I studied music,'' said Galway, 50, who is basing his stage movements on his observation of the chattering, black and white bird. Rossini wrote the opera using an actor as the magpie who stole the silver spoon and caused a young servant girl to be sentenced to death, but the Opera Company of Philadelphia revised the role for a musician. The rolling notes Galway plays as he flits about the stage were borrowed from passages Rossini wrote for the violin and flute as parts of the orchestra down in the pit.
