Galway, who turned 50 last year, plays opening night, April 16, and his wife and fellow performer, Jeanne, plays the magpie in the second and final performance. On April 17, he begins a tour in southern California that ends three weeks later in New York City.

Ray Combs, host of the television game show ``Family Feud,'' was arrested on a trespassing complaint after he appeared on the stage of the comedy club he co-owns. Combs' arrest when he left the CaddyCombs Comedy Club on Friday night was the latest legal action in a dispute about ownership and operation of the downtown club he and others opened in September. Combs, released later at police headquarters, said the arrest, based on a private complaint, was his first and called it ``the grossest injustice of human rights I have ever seen.'' He is scheduled to appear April 25 in Hamilton County Municipal Court. He has filed a lawsuit accusing Charles Schneider and the House Inc., owner of the building, have not kept separate the CaddyCombs and Caddy clubs, and has failed to maintain and to pay half the profits of the comedy club. William DeCenso, attorney for the House Inc. and Schneider, said his client did not want to comment on Combs' arrest.

Marvin Bush, youngest son of President Bush, has been named finance chairman of the Republican Party of Virginia while it recovers from a financial embarrassment. Last year, the state GOP cut staff and expenses after officials discovered a former bookkeeper had failed to pay withholding taxes for about 16 months. The party had to borrow to repay taxes of about $150,000 amd a $74,000 fine. ``One of my objectives is to make sure that things run as cleanly as possible,'' said Bush, who also will oversee the state party's fund-raising operations. Bush replaces state Sen. Edwina P. ``Eddy'' Dalton of Henrico County, who was the party's unsuccessful candidate for lieutenant governor last year. Bush worked for his father's presidential campaign in Virginia in 1988. He works in Alexandria for John Stewart Darrell and Co., a financial planning firm and acknowledges that his name won't hurt in GOP fund-raising. ``Being George Bush's son, there are some up sides to it,'' he said.

Media mogul Ted Turner attracted hundreds of farmers, ranchers and bargain-hunters to an auction of surplus equipment from his extensive holdings in southwest Montana. Saturday's auction, which offered everything from diesel tractors and hay bale stackers to irrigation pipe as he converts his Flying D Ranch from cattle to raising buffalo and trophy elk. The Flying D earlier sold about 11,000 cattle and began cutting back on growing hay at higher elevations to make room for the 3,000 to 4,000 buffalo that Turner wants to let roam, said ranch manager Bud Griffith. Last summer, the owner of WTBS in Atlanta _ who also owns professional sports teams and has other extensive business interests _ bought the Shelton Ranches, which include the Flying D, for a reported $20 million-plus. The holdings encompass 110,000 deeded acres and 20,000 leased acres between the Madison and Gallatin rivers. Turner put 107,000 acres under permanent conservancy to protect the land from development.

It's a dog's life, sometimes, for Doug Llewelyn, who interviews litigants on ``The People's Court'' and had one bite him on the knee. Celebrity magistrate Joseph A. Wapner had just heard the case of Anthony and Cynthia Patti of Highland, who said a neighbor boy had shot their dog, a Doberman-pit bull mix named Dee-Oh-Gee, in the eye with a pellet gun. According to a publicity release for the TV show, as Llewelyn had his customary chat with the adversaries after the court battle, Dee-Oh-Gee sunk his fangs into Llewelyn's right knee. A physician was called in to administer a tetanus shot. The dog owners ruefully explained that Dee-Oh-Gee had never acted mean before being shot. Llewelyn, who has four dogs of his own, accepted their apology. The dog owners won their case before Wapner, by the way, persuading the judge to put the bite on the neighbor boy's father for $300 in surgery costs for Dee-Oh-Gee.

Harrison Ford, whose breathtaking chase scenes have characterized his role as film adventurer Indiana Jones, stopped in this southern Wyoming town last week and quietly bought a new motorcycle. Linda Stance, a clerk at the Harley-Davidson of Green River motorcycle shop, said Ford spent about 45 minutes Thursday buying a 1990 black and cream Heritage model Harley. Stance said Ford, who owns land near Jackson, called earlier in the week to ask if the shop carried the motorcycle. Told the bike was available, he said he would fly to the Rock Springs Airport and would need a lift to the shop. Linda Laughlin, the shop's owner, gave Ford a ride from the airport to Green River, a community of about 10,000. At the shop, he posed for pictures with workers before he rode his new Harley out of town.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Might Mediate Lithuania Dispute if Asked
With AM-Soviet-Baltics
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican might mediate in the dispute over Lithuania's independence if it was asked to do so, the Holy See's envoy to the Soviet Union said in an interview published Sunday. The Roman Catholic newspaper Avvenire quoted Archbishop Francesco Colasuonno as saying that the conflict between Moscow and Lithuania over the republic's declaration of independence was ``a political question'' that could be dealt with by ``appropriate organs, such as the U.N.'' ``If, however, as a hypothesis, the Holy See was asked to carry out a task of persuasion or mediation, it is possible that it would do its best to reach a peaceful solution of the conflict,'' Colasuonno was quoted as saying. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has sent troops on patrol through Lithuania as part of a campaign of pressure since the republic declared independence on March 11. Colasuonno is due to travel to Moscow later this month as he begins his job as papal nuncio to the Soviet Union. He was named to the post last month when the Soviet Union and Vatican forged diplomatic ties for the first time since the formation of the Communist state. He noted that Pope John Paul II has called for dialogue to resolve the dispute over Lithuania, which is overwhelmingly Catholic. Colasuonno said he had ``reasons for optimism'' about Gorbachev's policy of perestroika, or economic restructuring, because of the developments in the Soviet Union in the past few years. Colasuonno, who has been a roving Vatican envoy to Eastern Europe, also said he expected diplomatic ties between the Holy See and Czechoslovakia to be restored before the pope visits the former Communist country April 21-22.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Declaration Should Be Withdrawn, Soviet Says
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet official said Sunday that Moscow is engaged in a ``political dialogue,'' with Lithuania, but a Lithuanian called the assertion a ``lie.'' Vitaly Churkin, an advisor to the Soviet foreign ministry, also said Lithuania should withdraw its declaration of independence so negotiations about the Baltic State's future can proceed. Churkin said Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's government wants to resolve the Lithuanian situation ``though political dialogue, and obviously this is what is going on now. We are thinking about it in those terms.'' Algimantis Cekuolis, a Lithuanian official, called that statement a ``lie.'' Both men appeared on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' ``They would be very happy to do anything to overthrow that (Lithuanian) government, like using a military force from inside and economical blockade from outside,'' Cekuolis said. ``That lie number three, that was told, that political dialogue going on ... There is no political dialogue, if you don't mean this Kalashnikov gun,'' he said. Lithuanians have tried to talk with the Soviets, but have only managed to get three hours of time from one of Gorbachev's deputies, he said. ``Please understand, they are not talking with us, but they are shouting all around the world that they are talking,'' he said. But Churkin said, ``If you want a divorce, you talk to your spouse, and it's either divorce after you settle all the issues which are involved, or maybe a reconciliation. ``We certainly would like to see a reconciliation, but who knows what the outcome is going to be.'' Churkin said the Lithuanians, who have demanded independence from Moscow, acted precipitiously in trying to secede before working out details of their future relationship with the Soviet Union on economic and other matters. ``Their declaration of independence, we feel, should be rescinded because it amounts to an ultimatum,'' he said. ``And before you declare your independence, you have to clear out some of the things which need to be resolved.''

DOC.HEAD: Survivor: Ferry Sank Minutes After Gale Struck; More Than 210 Feared Dead
DOC.TEXT: One of only 25 survivors rescued from a ferry that sank with about 240 people aboard said the boat went down minutes after being hit by gale-force winds, an official newspaper reported Sunday. At least 30 people drowned and as many as 180 others were missing and feared dead after the double-decker ferry Sein San Pya overturned Friday afternoon in the southern Gyaing River, official radio reports said. The latest radio report said 25 people had been rescued. The government-owned Working People's Daily quoted survivor Aung Mya Tint, a police inspector, as saying the vessel went down minutes after being struck by strong wind. The newspaper said the accident was due to natural forces rather than overloading. There are frequent ferry boat accidents in Burma due to overloading of passengers and cargo. The newspaper said the vessel could carry 280 passengers and up to 40 tons of cargo, noting the ferry that sank carried about 240 passengers and 19 tons of cargo. The ferry was making a regular run on the Gyaing River from the town of Moulmein eastward to the town of Kyondo in the southern province of Tenasserim, Radio Rangoon said. Moulmein is 100 miles southeast of Rangoon. The newspaper said doctors, Red Cross workers and local officials were providing medical treatment and other assistance to the survivors. Ferry accidents in southern Burma have claimed large numbers of lives in recent years. In May 1987, a old vessel with 400 people aboard overturned and sank in the Rangoon River. Reports at the time said 283 passengers were rescued but no official death toll was given. In October last year, 60 people were reported missing when a ferry with 170 people aboard sank in a storm near Rangoon.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Bailout May Require Tax Hike, GAO Head Says
DOC.TEXT: A tax increase will be needed at some point to pay for escalating losses among a third of the nation's savings and loan institutions, Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher said Sunday. Bowsher this past week raised the estimated pricetag for the government's S&L bailout from $257 billion to $325 billion with a warning that it could rise to $500 billion. ``This is one of the great financial disasters that we've ever had in this country and its going to have to be added onto all the other problems we have in the federal budget,'' he said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ``When you get done making the cuts that you hope you can make in defense and some of the other areas ... you're still going to have to look at the revenue side of the budget,'' the head of the congressional General Accounting Office said. Bowsher blamed the Bush administration's desire to meet deficit reduction targets without a tax increase for underestimating the size of the S&L problem. ``Last year they had unrealistic interests rates in their forecast,'' he said. ``They insisted on using a deposit assumption that ... gave you a 7 percent deposit growth _ where we knew that deposits were leaving. We told them at the time we'd probably be back, and that's where we are today.'' L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp., responsible for handling the bailout, said the government ``simply didn't know in what bad condition these S&Ls were.'' ``We found that there were more of them and in worse shape than we thought,'' Seidman said on the same show. ``One of the things everybody would like is to have it over in the near future. That just isn't going to happen. This is going to be with us for a long while, and it's going to be painful.''

DOC.HEAD: Modern Seders Vary, but Tradition Spans Thousands of Years
DOC.TEXT: There may be more varieties of matzoh now than when the Israelites fled from Egypt, but the essential elements of the Passover Seder haven't changed for thousands of years, making it one of the oldest ritual sit-down dinners. Perhaps the reason the feast commemorating the Exodus has survived so long is that its whole purpose is to pass on to generations of Jews the story of their ancestors' escape from slavery. On Monday at sundown, Jews all over the world will observe the tradition again. One professor of Jewish studies believes the gastronomic nature of the tradition may also have something to do with its longevity. ``If you can hit them in the stomach, it lasts,'' said Jon Levenson, a professor of Jewish studies at Harvard University. Elements of the family Seder as it is practiced today date back some 1,900 years, to the time of the destruction of the Second Temple in Jerusalem, Levenson said. Some parts of the tradition may date back roughly 3,000 years. Some scholars believe Jesus Christ's Last Supper was a Seder. ``That's unclear. It certainly took place around Passover time,'' Levenson said. There are Eastern religious meals that probably predate the Jewish Seder, but documentation to trace when they began is sketchy, according to religious scholars. The meaning of the Hebrew word for ``Passover'' is debatable, Levenson said. The popular explanation for the English word is that it describes the angel of death ``passing over'' the homes of Jews who marked their doors with lamb's blood. According to Exodus, the angel of death was sent to slay the Egyptians' firstborn. The modern explanation may be close to the original meaning of the word. Levenson believes the Hebrew word ``Pesach'' comes from a ritual dance. ``The verb itself I think means jump, leap,'' Levenson said. ``It may very well indicate that the destroyer in Exodus jumps'' over Jewish homes. The style of a modern Seder varies with each family. Some allow for long discussions, some are filled with song, others adopt modern themes. But the essential story, and many of the props that go with it, remain the same. Matzoh, the flat bread that now comes in whole wheat, egg and unsalted varieties, symbolizes that the Israelites fled so quickly from Pharaoh they didn't have time to let their bread rise. Bitter herbs, like horseradish, recall the bitter taste of slavery. And a sweet paste, often made of apples, raisins and nuts, represents the mortar the Jewish slaves used to build Egyptian pyramids. The Seder story is built around questions from children, usually posed by the youngest child at the table. The responses are framed so that even the child who doesn't know how to ask a question can learn the Exodus story. The Haggada is a book used to guide the meal. Traditional Haggadot contain prayers, blessings and appropriate readings. Some narratives are illustrated with pictures, others are specially made for children, and a feminist Haggada even appeared several years ago. References to the Holocaust, and to those lost in the Nazi death camps, are now common at many Seder tables. Some families use the Haggada as a starting point to lead into discussions of modern-day problems. Marvin Kalb, a former television correspondent who now directs a center on media studies at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, said talk at his family's Seder table often turns to newsworthy topics. ``We're very political and we do talk about modern themes, although we do go through the Passover readings in a very traditional way, '' Kalb said. Kalb said he still recalls cleaning the house and changing the dishes in his boyhood home to prepare for Passover. He said the Passover tradition has survived because it is built on an inherently interesting tale. ``It's a great story. It's a story of freedom,'' Kalb said. Author Elie Wiesel, who has written extensively about his experiences as a Holocaust survivor, said his family sticks closely to the traditional Haggada. ``It is linked to the first holiday, to the very beginning of history,'' said Wiesel, who teaches at Boston University. ``We are always fascinated with beginnings. After all, I think it's the first liberation story in history.''
