DOC.TEXT: Robert H. Reid has been the AP bureau chief in Manila since September 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Mattox Accuses Richards of Being Treated for Cocaine Addiction 10 Years Ago
With AM-Texas Governor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Jim Mattox accused rival Ann Richards in an interview broadcast Sunday of being treated for cocaine addiction 10 years ago, the latest in a series of drug-use accusations. ``I'm saying that she used cocaine at the age of 46 and marijuana, and she used other drugs,'' Mattox said in the interview broadcast on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' The attorney general said he obtained the information from mutual friends he declined to identify. Ms. Richards phoned the program to deny she'd ever sought treatment for cocaine use, but declined to appear on the show. A poll published Sunday showed Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, and Mattox virtually deadlocked as they headed into Tuesday's Democratic runoff. The winner will take on Republican candidate Clayton Williams in the general election. In appearances at inner-city churches in Houston and Dallas, the two candidates focused on their humble upbringings instead of the drug charges and countercharges that have dominated the campaign. The appearance on ``Face the Nation'' marked the first time that Mattox has accused Ms. Richards of requiring treatment for drug use. In 1980, she was treated at a Minnesota clinic for alcoholism. Ms. Richards dismissed Mattox's charge Saturday, when word of the pre-taped interview reached her. ``Jimmy's just going nuts,'' she said in Henderson. Last week, three people claimed they saw Mattox smoke marijuana on separate occasions in the 1970s. Mattox denied the accusations. Ms. Richards has answered questions about illegal drug use by saying she has not used a mood-altering drug in 10 years. She said Sunday she was sorry the campaign had become so acrimonious, but Mattox said the campaign's bitterness would not carry past Tuesday. ``We will be together in November because we have a common enemy at that time, and that will be Clayton Williams,'' Mattox said. Williams also appeared on ``Face the Nation,'' and said he wasn't sure whether he would dwell on drug allegations against the Democratic candidates. ``They've really worked it over with each other. I don't see a place for me to pick on them,'' he said. ``I'm going to be talking about the real issues.'' The poll published by the Houston Chronicle and The Dallas Morning News showed Ms. Richards and Mattox running virtually neck-and-neck. Of 759 Democrats who said they'd vote in the runoff, 44 percent backed Ms. Richards and 38 percent Mattox, and 16 percent said they were undecided, according to the poll. The telephone survey by the University of Houston had a margin of error of 4 percentage points, meaning a shift in the results could put Mattox ahead of Ms. Richards. In Houston, Mattox told Baptist congregations he had considered becoming a Baptist preacher while attending Baylor University. ``But I guess the worldly things got the best of me,'' said Mattox, who became a lawyer before becoming involved in politics. He asked for help during the campaign's final days. ``We must do more than just pray. We must get out and do the work, get out and vote,'' Mattox said. At a predominantly black church in Dallas, Ms. Richards said her election as governor would ``certainly be an announcement that times have changed in Texas. And when they open the door to me, they open it to all of you as well.'' ``I'm not here to tell you that I know what it is like to be denied opportunity because of my color,'' she said. ``But I am here to tell you I know what it is like to be denied opportunity and access to power and to the back room where decisions are made because I was born female.''

DOC.HEAD: Appomattox Surrender Recreated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to CORRECT that surrender of Lee to Grant not re-enacted; picks up penultimate graf, `Terry Daley ...'
DOC.TEXT: About 4,000 volunteers dressed as Union and Confederate soldiers Sunday marked the 125th anniversary of the end of the Civil War by recreating the solemn surrender of Gen. Robert E. Lee's troops. Nearly 8,000 spectators, some wearing bonnets and hoopskirts from 1865, stood behind wooden fences along the old stage road through Appomattox Court House National Historic Park. There was scattered applause and a few rebel yells as a man playing Confederate Gen. John Gordon rode a stocky chestnut horse in front of a column of rebel soldiers marching four abreast between Union troops with shouldered arms. After Appomattox, more than a month went by before the remaining Confederate armies surrendered and a few isolated forces west of the Mississippi River laid down their arms. But historians agree that Lee's surrender to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant ended the War Between the States for all intents and purposes. The re-enactment took place in the isolated, reconstructed central Virginia village where the war ended after four devastating years. Most of the volunteers playing rebel and Union men in uniform were grim. ``It's a solemn occasion,'' said Joe Pitts of Winston-Salem, N.C. ``We don't particularly care for it, and the troops back then didn't care for it.'' One young Confederate wept as he stacked his rifle in one of the teepee-style piles along the dirt road winding through the region's rolling hills. ``You get into what the soldiers felt back then,'' said Lake Day of Jacksonville, Fla. ``To subject yourself to surrender is tough.'' The volunteers said they were saddened this was the last major re-enactment of the anniversary battles they have recreated during the past four years. A few said they planned to quit the expensive hobby after this. The re-enactors ranged in age from pre-teens to septuagenarians, and came from across the United States, Canada and Europe. Pitts said they tried to depict the surrender at Appomattox exactly as the ragged, starving soldiers went through it. ``It can't be totally correct; we can't be emaciated like they were,'' he said. The re-enactment also was a few days off, and the sky was blue rather than gray. The stacking of arms came on April 12, 1865, exactly four years after the war started at Fort Sumter, S.C., and three days after Lee surrendered to Gen. Grant at a private home on the edge of the village. Lee's surrender was not re-enacted. Terry Daley of Baltimore, who played Union Gen. Joshua Chamberlain, said his order for his men to present arms as 27,800 Confederate soldiers surrendered, ``helped heal our wounds.'' ``At the sound of a bugle, Chamberlain paid the highest tribute you can to an adversary; it was to show we are brothers and Americans,'' Daley said.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze Smolders While Firefighters Bring Out Bodies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 9th graf pvs `In Oslo...' to UPDATE with American among missing and presumed dead, pickup graf 10 pvs, `Onso said...' ^By DOUG MELLGREN
DOC.TEXT: Exhausted firefighters braved metal-melting heat and poisonous smoke from a two-day-old fire Sunday to begin removing bodies of about 150 victims from the Scandinavian Star ferry. Firemen struggled to reach cabins where victims burned to death or suffocated in the suspicious blaze. It began before dawn Saturday while the ship was in the North Sea carrying about 500 tourists and crewmembers on an overnight trip from Norway to Demark. The heat was so intense Sunday that it melted aluminum aboard the bridge of the Danish-owned ship. Firefighters in masks and breathing equipment fought through one corridor ``until their gear started to burn,'' said fire consultant Olle Wennstrom. One firefighter was slightly injured, he said. Firemen were seen leaving the ship in tears during the night. Each firefighting team underwent psychological care after being relieved, officials said. The fire spread early Sunday from the gutted middle section to the captain's bridge a few hours after the blackened ship was towed into port. The blaze, which finally was extinguished late Sunday, sent plumes of smoke over Lysekil, on Sweden's southwest coast 250 miles southwest of Stockholm, the capital on the east coast. Tugboats doused the ship with water. Holes were blasted into the side of the 10,500-ton ship to allow the water to drain out, for fear that the badly listing ship would topple onto the concrete dock. Officials with VR-DANO Line, the company in Copenhagen that owns and operates the Bahamian-flagged ship, say the blaze was caused by arson, citing two fires that broke out at a short interval on two different decks. District police chief Roar Onso, revising earlier figures, said 345 people survived the fire, which broke out about midway on the ship's 10-hour voyage from Oslo to Frederikshavn. Ferry captain Hugo Larsen told police of 395 passengers and 97 crewmen. If his figure is correct, 147 people died, Osno said. In Oslo, police said six Americans of a seven-member entertainment troupe performing on the Scandanavian Star were were among the rescued. A seventh member, Ruth Rome, 27, of East Lansing, Mich., was missing and presumed dead, said Rick Qualls, another member of the group, from his Oslo hotel room. Onso said a burned passenger list was found in the debris but did not tally with the captain's account, and its accuracy was unclear. Forty-three bodies were removed from the the ferry before operations were suspended for the night. After a brief ceremony on the wharf, the victims were placed in a refrigerated truck and driven to Oslo for identification. Tickets were sold to car passengers according to the size of the car, not the number of people each was carrying. Children traveling free would not appear on any passenger list. Firemen found corpses in the corridors and cabins. A few drivers were found in their trucks on the car deck. Most victims were asphyxiated but some were charred beyond recognition. ``It will be very difficult to identify the victims. It will take a long time,'' Onso said. Onso confirmed reports that two fires broke out aboard the Scandinavian Star, but he refused to speculate on how that fitted with claims that the fire was deliberately set. One blaze started in a pile of sheets outside a cabin on a the car deck but was smothered by passengers, he said. A second fire started minutes later in a cabin one deck above the car deck, and it was apparently this blaze that turned the ship into a floating deathtrap. Onso said it would take several days to begin an on-site investigation of possible arson. A commission of inquiry would be set up to work parallel to a police probe. The first bodies emerged from the ship in metal containers. A memorial service was planned in Oslo's main cathedral on Tuesday for the Norwegians, who comprised most of the casualties. Fifty-two survivors who were picked up by a Soviet freighter from lifeboats were kept in isolation under the care of psychiatrists in Lysekil, 45 miles north of Goteborg. Relatives of the casualties began reaching the town of 8,000 people, and also were assisted by teams of psychiatrists and nurses. Passengers accused the crew of being untrained and ill prepared for an emergency. The Danish Seamen's Union issued a harsh condemnation of the behavior of the Danish captain and crewmen, who were mostly Filipinos and Portuguese. It accused crewmen of abandoning ship before evacuating passengers. ``Danish seamen would not leave a burning ship as long as there were passengers on board,'' said union chairman Preben Moller Hansen. Passengers spoke of chaos as the fire spread through the ship, and little help from the crew who could not communicate with them. Lifeboats were left dangling on the ship and life jackets were unavailable, they said. In another ferry disaster, in Burma, one of only 25 survivors rescued from a ferry that sank with about 240 people aboard said the craft went down just minutes after a storm hit, the government-owned Working People's Daily reported Sunday. The ferry capsized and sank in gale-force winds Friday while carrying passengers on a southern Burmese river between the towns of Moulmein and Kyondo. Official Burmese radio reports say at least 30 people drowned and 180 others are missing and feared dead. The newspaper said the accident on the Gyaing River was not due to overloading. Frequent ferry boat accidents in Burma have been due to overloading of passengers and cargo.

DOC.HEAD: Three Youngsters Die in Apartment Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire swept through an apartment in this Denver suburb Sunday morning, killing three children and injuring their mother, who screamed, ``Let it be a dream!'' Two firefighters also suffered injuries. The mother, Debra Potter, 28, managed to escape and had to be kept from running back into the building. She was hospitalized with unspecified injuries. The fire broke out around 7:15 a.m., and was confined to the two-story home in the apartment complex, officials said. Firefighters entered the apartment to try to rescue the children, but were driven back by the intense heat, officials said. One firefighter was injured by falling debris inside the building; another suffered minor injuries. Killed were Steven Potter, 7, Kristina Potter, 5, and Daniel Potter, 4, the Fire Department said. Witnesses said they heard a child screaming inside the house. Mike Bannister, who lives in the complex, said he restrained Mrs. Potter as she tried to return inside the building. ``She was outside running around, just running around hysterically screaming,'' Bannister said. ``She was getting ready to run back in, but I grabbed her because I realized it was just too late.'' Another neighbor, Ruth Santos, said Mrs. Potter was screaming, ``Let it be a dream! Let it be a dream!'' The cause of the blaze was under investigation, said city Fire Marshal Doug Hall. ``For now, this is nothing but an accidental fire,'' Hall said. ``We have no information to make any determination.''

DOC.HEAD: Faldo Wins 2nd Sudden-Death Masters
DOC.TEXT: Englishman Nick Faldo beat Ray Floyd on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff Sunday at the Masters Tournament, duplicating exactly his win last year in the prestigious tourney. ``I made history today,'' said Faldo, who joined Jack Nicklaus as the only other person to win consecutive Masters. Faldo also won last year on the 11th hole in sudden death. He took home $225,000. Floyd, a 1976 Masters winner who at 47 was trying to become the oldest person to win in Augusta, made $135,000. Both finished regulation play at 10-under-par 278. Faldo shot 69 Sunday, and Floyd a par 72. Faldo had to recover from a terrible start Sunday. He displayed enormous patience and perserverance in his comeback, making up three strokes on Floyd in the last four holes. He was also greatly helped by Floyd, who missed a makeable birdie on the first playoff hole, No. 10, then put his second shot into the water on No. 11. On the 11th, Faldo made par, turned to shake Floyd's hand, then hugged his caddy. Floyd was devasted by his loss. ``The shot on the 11th was in the water the moment it left my club,'' he said. ``It's the most devastating thing that has happened to me in golf. ``I've lost before, but never like this. I've never had anything affect me like this. I've never felt like this.''

DOC.HEAD: Mattox, Richards Down to the Wire In Texas Democratic Runoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7, `Ms. Richards ...,' to CORRECT that Ms. Richards virtually deadlocked with opponent, sted slightly ahead, because of poll's margin of error.
DOC.TEXT: As Ann Richards and Jim Mattox near the finish in the Democratic runoff for governor, the issues have disappeared under a cloud of personal attacks focusing on accusations of illegal drug use by both candidates. The only ones seeming to enjoy it were Republicans, who nominated oilman-rancher Clayton Williams last month in a landslide. ``The Democratic Veg-O-Matic primary is what I call it _ slice and dice,'' said Karl Rove, a consultant. ``On the scale of more vicious campaigns, this ranks near the top.'' Mattox, who made an issue of Ms. Richards' refusal to answer questions about drug use more than a decade ago, fended off allegations again Saturday that he smoked marijuana in the 1970s. ``Jim Mattox has never used any kind of dangerous drug, ever,'' he said in Houston. Ms. Richards was virtually deadlocked with her rival before Tuesday's runoff, according to a poll in Sunday's editions of The Dallas Morning News and the Houston Chronicle. The winner will face Williams in the November election to succeed retiring Gov. Bill Clements, the only Republican governor in Texas in the past 100 years. The poll showed Ms. Richards backed by 44 percent of voters who said they plan to vote in Tuesday's runoff, with Mattox drawing 38 percent, 16 percent undecided and 3 percent not supporting either candidate. The poll of 759 voters by the Center for Public Policy at the University of Houston has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.l As election day neared, both candidates complained about the campaign's direction. ``I feel badly for the electorate, really, that this campaign has taken this tone,'' said Ms. Richards. ``We haven't talked nearly enough about the issues in this campaign,'' said Mattox, who described the race as ``a full-contact sport.'' A sampling: _ Mattox claimed to have witnesses who saw Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, use drugs. But he wouldn't release their names or any proof. Ms. Richards said, ``I don't know what he's talking about.'' _ Two newspapers reported allegations by a Houston lawyer and former Dallas policeman that they had seen Mattox smoke marijuana on separate occasions in the 1970s. Mattox said, ``Get those two folks, sit them right here with me. I'll tell them they are liars to their faces.'' _ Ms. Richards aired a television commercial showing a cartoon Mattox figure hurling mud patties at a photo of her holding her granddaughter. An announcer says: ``He's at it again. The same old politics. Mudslinging and negative campaigning.'' _ Mattox aired a commercial that asked without offering evidence, ``Did she use marijuana or something worse like cocaine? Not as a college kid but as a 47-year-old elected official sworn to uphold the law?'' _ Ms. Richards said Mattox had profited from public service and wanted to ``cover up'' a $200,000 payment from a Dallas developer indicted for racketeering. She also ripped Mattox's refusal to disclose his income tax returns. _ Mattox charged that the Richards campaign was ``peddling their smut and their dirt'' because she didn't want to discuss issues and wouldn't face him in a debate before the election. _ Former Gov. Mark White, defeated in the March 13 primary, said he'd never vote for Ms. Richards because of behavior that ``would make (Nazi war criminal Heinrich) Himmler blush.'' But he withheld his endorsement from Mattox. Rove said the Democrats had opened doors for Williams. ``They've raised issues in the primary that may or may not have been raised in the general election,'' said Rove. ``But now they can be raised without the shrillness and viciousness that might have been there otherwise.'' In her campaign, Ms. Richards, 56, the state treasurer, offered a vision of what she called ``the new Texas.'' She said her priorities as governor would be education, the economy, ethics in government and protection of the environment. She pointed to her record as a moneymaking treasurer. Mattox, 46, pointed to his record of public service as a Dallas County prosecutor, congressman and two-term attorney general. He also offered what he said was the only hope for improved education and law enforcement without a tax increase: a state lottery. Many of the candidates' comments dwelled on each other's tactics. Mattox on his rival: ``I said I was concerned about the political cannibalism that was taking place. We made a good effort try to get Ann Richards to step back away from that approach to politics.'' Ms. Richards on hers: ``I really thought when Mattox began all this (drug) stuff, for the provocation of it, the sort of witch hunt that he was on, I just thought the whole thing was sick. I still do, regardless of who they're talking about.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Claim Victory With 150 Sure Seats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with conservatives claiming victory, quotes from Mitsotakis and Papandreou, updated vote totals; pickup graf 11 pvs, `The deadlock...' ^By TERRY LEONARD
DOC.TEXT: The conservative New Democracy party claimed victory Sunday after it captured about half the seats in Greece's third parliamentary election in 10 months. But it remained uncertain if the party would win the outright majority that would enable it to break the country's political deadlock without help from outside its ranks. Returns showed New Democracy, which barely missed majorities in the inconclusive elections last June and November, had won at least 150 of the 300 seats in Parliament. Party leader Constantine Mitsotakis said his party was assured of only 150 seats, but he declared victory anyway and said he believed he would form a government Wednesday. ``In today's elections, the Greek people decided: they gave the victory to New Democracy,'' he said. ``I feel great responsibility, and we celebrate our victory.'' Mitsotakis said he didn't yet know if his party had won 150 or 151 seats but was sure that he would be given the mandate to form a government. Caretaker Interior Minister Theodore Katrivanos told reporters early Monday that New Democracy was close to an outright majority in the 300-member single-house Parliament. ``New Democracy has 150 seats with the possibility of gaining more and only a slight possibility of getting less,'' said Katrivanos, who based his comments on official returns. Two major independent Athens television stations declared New Democracy the winner, saying their projections showed the conservatives would win 151 to 152 seats. The declarations sparked early morning horn honking, fireworks and wild street celebrations in the capital by flag-waving party loyalists. Returns from 15,870 of 16,584 polling stations showed New Democracy with 47.1 percent of the vote, compared to 38.6 for former Premier Andreas Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK), 10.07 percent for the Communist-led alliance of leftist parties and 4.2 percent for small parties and independents. New Democracy, which got 46.19 percent of the vote and 148 seats in November's election, needed only about a 1 percent increase its vote to win a majority Sunday. PASOK and the Communist-led alliance, which were not considered strong enough to win outright, worked together to try to prevent a conservative victory and to forge their own coalition government. Papandreou criticized Mitsotakis in his only comments early Monday but did not concede defeat, saying the distribution of seats in crucial areas was hard to judge. ``I'd like to stress that Mr. Mitsotakis has led the country to three consecutive elections in pursuit of self-sufficiency, trying to set the dilemma before the people of government or no government, instead of posing the question of which government with which policy,'' he said. ``These elections were the last thing needed by our country.'' ``PASOK will wage its battle both inside and outside of Parliament, defending the people's national and economic issues,'' Papandreou said early Monday. Miltiades Evert, a top New Democracy official and former Athens mayor, said projections that showed the conservatives had won at least 150 seats meant New Democracy was in control and could prevent any coalition by other parties. ``It is certain that New Democracy has 150 seats, and New Democracy now controls political developments. Without New Democracy, nothing can be done,'' he told Greek television. The political deadlock has been hard to break in Greece, where party loyalty often translates into jobs and loans. Both PASOK and the conservatives have governed Greece since the military dictatorship ended in 1974. But big changes in party totals are difficult to achieve. The deadlock itself has become an issue because the weak coalitions formed after the June and November elections were unable to cope with a foundering economy and a resurgence of political terrorism. ``I believe the Greek people have realized that the crisis the country is going through is a fundamental and dangerous one,'' said Constantine Karamanlis, the six-term former conservative premier and one-term president who led Greece back to democracy after military rule. Greece faces severe economic problems. The budget deficit has soared to $15.6 billion and the inflation rate, the highest in the Common Market, hit 17.8 percent last month. In June, voters rejected the scandal-tainted PASOK government of Papandreou but denied a majority to 71-year-old conservative leader Constantine Mitsotakis. A conservative-Communist coalition formed after the June election, and it indicted Papandreou and some of his ministers on corruption charges. No trial date, has been set, however, and the charismatic former premier remains a political force despite the indictment, health problems and an open affair with Dimitri Liani, a former airline hostess half his age whom he married after divorcing his American wife of 38 years. The weak coalition governments that ruled following the June and November elections also postponed decisions on a U.S. extradition request for a Palestinian wanted for the bombing of an airliner in 1982 over Hawaii and on a new military bases agreement with the United States. The four U.S. military bases in Greece could close in November unless a new agreement is reached with Washington. Two of the four bases already have been slated for closure by the Pentagon in cost-cutting measures.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Gain Overwhelming Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after graf 8 pvs, `Their closest...' to RAISE descriptions of party platforms; pickup graf 9 pvs `The agrarian-based...'; EDITS to conform
DOC.TEXT: Voters choosing Hungary's first freely elected government in 43 years gave an overwhelming victory Sunday to Hungary's main conservative party, according to final unofficial results. It was the second conservative sweep in Eastern Europe in as many free elections. East Germans gave conservatives a clear victory in elections on March 18, relegating the Communists to an opposition role. In Hungary, Democratic Forum President Jozsef Antall declared, ``I am completely certain that we won the elections. ``But it is not we, but the Hungarian people who have won these elections,'' he said to jubilant supporters crowding party headquarters six hours after polls closed. He turned 58 Sunday, and a rare smile creased his face as he was presented with a gigantic boquet of flowers. Final official results for the 261 parliamentary seats at stake in runoff elections Sunday were not expected before Tuesday. The results were combined with elections held March 25 for a total of 386 seats in the 394-member parliament. Eights seats will be allocated based on minority representation. The national vote counting center reporting unofficial results show the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum winning 42.7 percent of the vote. That gave the party 165 seats after both rounds. Their closest rivals, the liberal Alliance of Free Democrats, won 23.8 percent of the vote, or a total of 92 seats. The Free Democrats want to quickly scrap Hungary's command economy in favor of a market economy. The Forum emphasizes traditional Christian values and cautious economic change. The agrarian-based Smallholders party won 43 districts with 11.1 percent of the vote, while reform Communists grouped in the Socialist Party had won 33 with 8.55 percent. The Federation of Young Democrats and the Christian Democrats won 21 seats with 5.4 percent of the vote each. The other 11 seats were divided among six independents, four candidates supported by several parties, and a candidate of the splinter Agrarian Federation. Direct voting Sunday determined 171 of the 261 seats at stake. Ninety seats will be determined on the voting percentage each party receives. The early conservative advantage forced a concession from Free Democrat leader Miklos Haraszti. ``It is clear that the HDF will gain the most seats,'' he said. Elections two weeks ago left 261 of the National Assembly's 394 seats undecided. That balloting gave no party an outright majority but relegated the former Communists to fourth place. No party was considered strong enough to win a majority in Sunday's polling and a coalition government was expected. More than 7.5 million people were eligible to vote. Both front-running parties, the Democratic Forum and the Free Democrats, have refused to consider forming a government with the former Communists. Most polls closed at 6 p.m. after 12 hours of voting. State television began its 24-hour election program two hours later with preliminary estimates of a more than 40 percent turnout nationwide, indicating that more than 3.25 million people voted. Many Hungarians seemed weary after the second round of balloting in two weeks. ``It's clear that people have become tired,'' Interim President Matyas Szueros told reporters before casting his ballot. ``It's time to end the election process.'' The voting was generally uneventful, with few irregularities reported. In Debrecen, about 90 miles west of the capital of Budapest, several polling stations did not open on time because supervisory officials were late, state radio reported. One station first opened at 9 a.m., three hours past schedule. The radio said the delay was caused by the chief supervisor who called in to say he would be late because ``he was tired.'' Voters at a polling station in Budapest shook out umbrellas after walking in from the rain, and many clutched pussy willows symbolic in Hungary of Easter. Many said they were enthusiastic about voting in the national elections, but others appeared skeptical that a new government would be able to solve Hungary's severe economic problems that include a declining living standard, double-digit inflation, growing unemployment and a $20 billion foreign debt. ``I'm here, I'm voting but I don't have any confidence in it,'' said Ernoe Horvath, a 61-year old retiree. ``Even now we don't have people (running) that we can trust.'' The first round of elections on March 25 put the Hungarian Democratic Forum and the liberal Alliance of Free Democrats in the lead, but neither party polled a majority, forcing Sunday's second round. The Socialists were unique among ruling Soviet bloc parties in leading their country to democracy without massive popular pressure. But most people associate the party with the excesses of 43 years of Communist rule. The Free Democrats have warmed in recent weeks to the possibility of a coalition with the Democratic Forum. But the Forum has said it will only join forces with the Free Democrats in a ``national emergency.'' Antall refused to comment when asked Sunday about the possibility of a coalition government with the Free Democrats. But Free Democrat leader Janos Kis said that ``a grand coalition is a distinct possibility which we don't refuse because we are ... for having a government with wide popular support.''

DOC.HEAD: Auction of Items from Liberace's Home Brings $300,000
DOC.TEXT: A mink bedspread lined with silk and trimmed with mink tails sold for $9,900 Sunday as more than 2,000 items from entertainer Liberace's estate went up for auction. The late, flamboyant pianist's trademark candelabra, silver and a Steinway grand piano were among the furnishings and artwork sold from ``The Cloisters,'' his Palm Springs estate, an auction spokeswoman said. The sale raised $300,000, with proceeds benefiting the Liberace Foundation for the Performing and Creative Arts, which provides scholarships to students of the arts. ``The auction overall was a terrific success,'' said Laura Smissaert, spokeswoman for Butterfield & Butterfield, which conducted the sale. ``We had standing-room only crowds and made a considerable amount of money for the Liberace Foundation.'' About 800 people attended, with more than 500 registered to bid, Ms. Smissaert said. The auction's highest bid was for a 1977 Auburn supercharged ``boattail'' speedster, painted crimson with a gold coach lining. The automobile, with an interior trimmed in burgundy leather, has a Lincoln engine but holds only one gallon of gasoline. The car, which went for $18,700, was used in Liberace's Las Vegas stage act and the little gas tank was a safety requirement, Ms. Smissaert said. The black mink bedspread's silk lining bears the Liberace logo, a stylized cursive L, and is large enough for a king-size bed, Ms. Smissaert said. The white and gold Steinway and Sons grand piano, which went for $17,000, more than twice its estimated price, was one of the other lavish items sold, she said. A collection of 30 toy cars given to Liberace by fans sold for $800, and a brass bed from the estate's ``Rudolph Valentino suite'' went for $3,850. While the items from the estate were luxurious, Ms. Smissaert said the furnishings were as functional as they were grand. ``This was his favorite home and therefore not as outrageous,'' she said. ``Anybody who walked through the house got a sense that it was a very livable place.'' The mansion, which Liberace purchased in 1967, was dubbed The Cloisters because of its walls and alcoves. The property was sold after the entertainer's death from AIDS in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Vargas Llosa Wins in Peru's Elections, Projections Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with two more dead, one wounded in rebel violence; pickup graf three `The Maoist...'; INSERT one graf after 27th `Army forces...' with details; pickup graf 28 pvs `In Lima...'
DOC.TEXT: Celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa won the first round of presidential elections Sunday, but he fell far short of the majority needed to avoid a runoff, according to unofficial projections. Rebels trying to sabotage the elections attacked some polling stations in Lima with dynamite Sunday, but no one was reported injured. Weekend guerrilla violence in Peru killed at leaast 28 people and wounded 44, authorities said. The Maoist Shining Path has assassinated six congressional candidates and killed or wounded dozens of other people in recent weeks, aiming to disrupt the election. Vargas Llosa, 54, of the center-right Democratic Front coalition, has run on a free-market ticket. He said the results showed voters had rejected leftist policies and the governing left-of-center Aprista Party for its ``catastrophic five years in government.'' ``The country's political panorama has changed profoundly with this election,'' he said. The novelist captured 36.8 percent of the vote based on results from an exit poll by APOYO, a market research firm. APOYO said Alberto Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, was in second place in its projections with 26.7 percent. Fujimori is a political independent who was virtually unknown to Peruvian voters as recently as a month ago. Peruvian Public Opinion projected 33.1 percent as Vargas Llosa's final tally and 26.2 percent for Fujimori. APOYO, one of Peru's most respected polling firms, said its results were based on the initial 54 percent of its total interviews done nationwide. It said that was a big enough sample to project a final vote. The market research firm also said Aprista Party candidate Luis Alva Castro had 13.2 percent of the votes in its projections. It said Henry Pease, candidate of the United Left, had 7 percent while Alfonso Barrantes, candidate of the Socialist Left, 4 percent. The rest of the votes were spread among four minor party candidates and blank or nullified votes, according to APOYO. Officials returns are not expected for weeks. The Peruvian Public Opinion poll had similar figures for the other candidates. At a news conference, Vargas Llosa proposed that he and Fujimori meet to discuss ways to avoid a second election, saving Peru from the turmoil of two more months of campaigning. Fujimori arrived minutes later at the news conference and congratulated Vargas Llosa. But at a later news conference, he rejected any possibility of stepping aside to avoid a runoff. ``I believe a second round is necessary to debate our proposals,'' he said. ``The verdict should be the public's.'' During the campaign, Vargas Llosa has sharply attacked the Aprista Party and the two leftist alliances. He is unlikely to have their support in the runoff. In contrast, Fujimori has run a conciliatory campaign without attacks. He is believed to have support within the Aprista Party. ``The left is not going to support the Democratic Front because of the polarization that has been generated in the country,'' Fujimori said in a news conference after polls closed at 5 p.m. The campaign has brought a surge in popularity for Fujimori. Last week, Fujimori, 51, rose into second place in voter surveys, displacing Alva Castro, 48. The Peruvian Public Opionion projections of the final vote also indicated the Democratic Front would win only 23 seats in the 60-seat senate and 63 seats in the 180-seat chamber of deputies. That would make it very difficult for Vargas Llosa, 54, to impose the severe austerity measures he has pledged if he wins. He says radical economic reforms are needed to revive Peru's moribund economy and turn Peru into a ``modern nation'' free of the socialist policies he says have stiffled growth for two decades. Inflation is running at more than 2,000 percent annually. Voters are choosing a president to replace populist Alan Garcia, whose five-year term ends July 28. He is legally ineligible to serve a consecutive term. During Sunday's voting, soldiers armed with automatic weapons protected polling stations against terrorist attacks. Leftist guerrillas exploded sticks of dynamite near two polling stations early Sunday in downtown Lima and an outlying shantytown. Police said the explosions caused no damage and no one was injured. The government said nearly 80,000 policemen were on alert throughout the country. More than 200,000 army troops were providing security in the country's mountainous emergency zones, where guerrillas are most active. On Saturday, police said Maoist Shining Path guerrillas blew up municipal buildings and sacked stores, killing 17 peasants and wounding 13 in the mountain village of Santo Thomas de Pata, about 18 miles northwest of Ayacucho. Army forces retailated Sunday, tracking down the rebels and killing six in a fierce firefight, police said. One soldier was also killed in the battle. Also Sunday, two members of the Shining Path were killed in the central Andes when the bomb they were planting on a bridge exploded, authorities said. Another rebel was badly wounded in the blast in the town of Huasquis, about 100 miles east of Lima. In Lima, where one-third of Peru's voters live, police patrolled the streets in armored vehicles and diverted traffic around the capital's 15,837 polling stations. People entering voting stations were searched for weapons. The government asked voters to go to the polls empty-handed to facilitate searches. Fear of rebel attacks paralyzed bus traffic between towns in mountainous insurgency zones. But election officials said voter turnout was heavy, despite threats by the Shining Path guerrilla group to kill voters and candidates. Television stations showed lines of voters up to five blocks long in Huancayo, in the Andes 120 miles east of Lima. Huancayo, a major trading center, is a Shining Path stronghold. In some areas of the country election officials suspended the requirement that voters dip their index fingers into indelible ink after casting ballots. The guerrillas have killed highland peasants and cut off their hands as a warning not to vote. Voters leaving polling stations Sunday morning in the working-class neighborhood of La Victoria expressed support mainly for Fujimori and Vargas Llosa, who put aside his writing two years ago to campaign for the presidency. Mariana Pino de Grecia, a housewife, said she voted for Vargas Llosa. ``The country needs someone known internationally to attract aid. Fujimori is not known. He doesn't have a plan of government and he's too new,'' she said. But taxi driver Angel Torres said he voted for Fujimori. ``Let's see what Fujimori can do,'' he said. ``The others are old politicians. He's more honorable, harder-working.'' Voting is required by law. Violators are subject to heavy penalties, including a fine equivalent to half the monthly minimum wage of $45. The Maoist Shining Path guerrilla group launched its insurgency in May 1980 by burning ballot boxes near the highland city of Ayacucho. Since then nearly 20,000 people have been killed in political violence, including rebels, police, soldiers and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pepsi To Be Traded For Soviet Vodka and Ships
DOC.TEXT: Pepsico Inc. and the Soviet Union are expected to sign an agreement to trade Pepsi-Cola for ships and vodka, which would be the largest deal between that country and a U.S. corporation, The New York Times reported. The deal is valued at more than $3 billion and is expected to be announced Monday, the Times reported in Monday editions. The agreement would make Pepsi-Cola much more available in the Soviet Union while enabling Pepsico to take out its profits not just in the form of Stolichnaya vodka but in oceangoing freighters and tankers. The agreement is being watched as an indicator of whether Western companies can succeed in the Soviet Union, the newspaper said. The Purchase, N.Y.-based company became the first large U.S. company to enter the Soviet Union in 1974, when it began trading Pepsi for Stolichnaya. Pepsico ships its soft-drink syrup to the Soviet Union, where it is made into cola and sold in bottles. The vodka was sold through a third party in the United States. The new deal calls for the Soviet Union to trade at least 10 tankers with a total value of $300 million, the Times said. The agreement would also allow Pepisco to sell Pepsi in plastic bottles and aluminium cans instead of just glass bottles, and calls for increasing the number of bottling plants from 26 to 50, the newspaper said. ``This deal is going to make the Soviet Union a very big business for us,'' John Swanhaus, president of Pepsico's Wines and Spirits subsidiary, told the Times. Pepsi sells in the Soviet Union for the equivalent of 75 cents for an 11-ounce bottle.

DOC.HEAD: Crew Member Dead, Nine Injured in Ferry Fire Off Britain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with nine injured; firefighters brought out by helicopter; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ferry Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out Monday on a car ferry carrying 297 people from Britain's west coast to Ireland, killing a crew member and injuring nine people, officials said. The fire broke out beneath the car deck as the B and I ferry Norrano was eight miles west of the Welsh coast, the coast guard said. Spokesman George Clarke said the fire was brought under control. A Royal Air Force spokesman said one crew member had been killed. Clarke said the injured, including a pregnant women, were suffering from smoke inhalation. He said they had been evacuated to Withybush Hospital in Haverford West by three RAF helicopters. ``The first helicopter brought out eight firefighters, and then we brought out two doctors with oxygen equipment,'' Clarke said. The ferry, carrying 78 crew members and 219 passengers, was en route from Milford Haven, 180 miles west of London, to Rosslare, Ireland. The coast guard spokesman said the vessel was returning to Milford Haven under its own power.

DOC.HEAD: Executive Shakeup at Troubled Taj
DOC.TEXT: The Trump Organization is planning a shakeup among executives at the newly-opened Taj Mahal Casino Resort, whose slot machines have repeatedly been shut down by overuse, a spokeswoman said Sunday. However, owner Donald Trump said in a statement that none of the proposed changes resulted from the slot-machine troubles at the 1,250-room casino hotel _ Atlantic City's biggest _ that opened last Monday. The Taj's 3,000 slot machines were shut down Friday night after the volume of action overburdened the casino. The machines had opened six hours late that day because of staff shortages and problems accounting for the amount of money in the machines. They remained closed during the weekend and will be out of service indifinitely to allow for procedural changes, officials said. Taj Mahal Executive Vice President W. Bucky Howard is to become president and chief operations officer at the casino, said spokeswoman Karon Tuso. ``As a casino operator, Bucky is one of the best,'' Trump said in the statement read by Ms. Tuso. ``He will provide the leadership that will ensure the Trump Taj Mahal its place as the world's greatest casino and convention resort.'' Howard would replace Walter J. Haybert, who has been president and chief executive officer since last October. Haybert would become chief financial officer. Edward Tracy would be named president and chief executive officer of Trump Hotel Corp. while continuing as president and chief operations officer of Trump Castle Casino Resort, a position he has held since November, Ms. Tuso said. The Trump Hotel Corp. manages Trump's four Atlantic City properties. Ms. Tuso said the proposed changes must first be approved by the state Casino Control Commission. Haybert was vice president of Harrah's in 1984 when it managed Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. At the time, more than 50 percent of the Plaza's slots machines were closed during its first three weeks, and Haybert resigned midway through that crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Prices Make Seasonal Rise
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices rose an average of 2.35 cents a gallon over the past two weeks as spring vacationers took to the road, a survey released has concluded. The Lundberg Survey of 13,000 gas stations nationwide, completed on Friday and released Sunday, put the national average price for a gallon of gas at 113.31 cents. The average covers all grades of gas, types of service and all taxes. Price rises were especially high in the Midwest, survey chief Trilby Lundberg said. She suggested that higher freight and distribution costs to the Midwest may have contributed to the price increases. Retailers faced a margin pinch as the increase in retail prices lagged behind gains in wholesale prices, Lundberg said. The average wholesale posting for a gallon of gas, not including rebates and other price breaks, was 75.35 cents a gallon for the same two-week period, a 3.5 cent increase over the last survey, she said. Here are the Lundberg survey average prices: _ Self-service stations: regular unleaded, 101.53 cents a gallon; premium unleaded 118.77 cents; regular leaded, 100.58 cents. _ Full-service stations: regular unleaded, 129.47 cents a gallon; premium unleaded, 142.93 cents; regular leaded, 128.42 cents. The survey indicates more than 80 percent of gasoline retail sales are at self-service stations.
